editionStmt.edition: This early release includes some 500 EEBO-TCP transcriptions of Early Modern plays that have undergone several routines to create an interoperable and algorithmically amenable corpus of Early Modern Drama. Many incompletely or incorrectly transcribed words have been corrected, including obvious printers' errors, but the text has not been proofread word by word. Each word in the text has been identified as a distinct token with its own xml:id and assigned to a lemma, a part of speech, and a standard spelling. Speech prefixes were mapped to unique speaker ID's as "who" attributes of sp elements. elements

respStmt.resp: Incompletely or incorrectly transcribed words were reviewed and in many cases fixed by
respStmt.name: Melina Yeh

respStmt.resp: Tokenization and linguistic annotation using MorphAdorner and NUPOS 2.0 were provided by
respStmt.name: Philip R. Burns

respStmt.resp: With the help of Thomas L. Berger's Index of Characters in Early Modern English Drama Printed Plays, 1500-1660 speech prefixes were mapped to unique "who" attributes of sp elements by
respStmt.name: Martin Mueller

respStmt.resp: A provisional, rudimentry, and algorithmically produced castlist was added as a new div in the back listing each role with their number of speeches sorted from high to low by
respStmt.name: Martin Mueller

respStmt.resp: Project co-ordination and review of textual changes and linguistic annotation by
respStmt.name: Martin Mueller

publicationStmt.publisher: Printed for Humphrey Robinson ... and for Humphrey Moseley ...,

note.p: "Never printed before, and now published by the authours originall copies"
First folio; includes the plays not hitherto printed, except the Wild-goose chase, which was missing, but recovered and printed in 1652. Cf. NUC pre-1956.
"The Epistle dedicatorie" is signed by John Lowin, Joseph Taylor, and eight others; "To the reader" signed by Ja. Shirley, who is usually regarded as the editor.
For complete contents of this edition, see NUC pre-1956 imprints.
Reproduction of original in Harvard University Libraries.

div.head: Scaena prima.
div.stage: Enter Bonduca, daughters, Hengo, Nennius, soldiers.

sp.speaker: Bon.
sp.l: The hardy Romans? O ye gods of Britain,
The rust of arms, the blushing shame of soldiers;
Are these the men that conquer by inheritance?
The fortune-makers? these the Julians,
That with the sun measure the end of nature,
Making the world but one Rome and one Caesar?
Shame, how they flee! Caesar's soft soul dwells in 'em;
Their mothers got 'em sleeping, pleasure nursed 'em,
Their bodies sweat with sweet oils, loves allurements,
Not lusty arms. Dare they send these to seek us,
These Roman girls? Is Britain grown so wanton?
Twice we have beat 'em, Nennius, scattered 'em,
And through their big-boned Germans, on whose pikes
The honour of their actions sit in triumph,
Made themes for songs to shame 'em, and a woman,
A woman beat 'em, Nennius; a weak woman,
A woman beat these Romans.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: So it seems.
A man would shame to talk so.

sp.speaker: Bon.
sp.l: Who's that?

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: I.

sp.speaker: Bon.
sp.l: Cousin, do you grieve my fortunes?

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: No, Bonduca,
If I grieve, 't is the bearing of your fortunes;
You put too much wind to your sail: discretion
And hardy valour are the twins of honour,
And nursed together, make a conqueror:
Divided, but a talker. 't is a truth,
That Rome has fled before us twice, and routed;
A truth we ought to crown the gods for, lady,
And not our tongues. A truth is none of ours,
Nor in our ends, more than the noble bearing:
For then it leaves to be a virtue, lady;
And we that have been victors, beat ourselves,
When we insult upon our honours subject.

sp.speaker: Bon.
sp.l: My valiant cousin, is it foul to say
What liberty and honour bid us do,
And what the gods allow us?

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: No, Bonduca,
So what we say, exceed not what we do.
Ye call the Romans fearful, fleeing Romans,
And Roman girls, the lees of tainted pleasures:
Does this become a doer? are they such?

sp.speaker: Bon.
sp.l: They are no more.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: Where is your conquest then?
Why are your altars crowned with wreathes of flowers,
The beasts with gilt horns waiting for the fire?
The holy druids composing songs
Of everlasting life to victory?
Why are these triumphs, lady? for a may-game?
For hunting a poor herd of wretched Romans?
Is it no more? shut up your temples, Britain's,
And let the husbandman redeem his heifers;
Put out our holy fires; no timbrel ring;
Let's home, and sleep; for such great overthrows,
A candle burns too bright a sacrifice,
A glow-worm's tail too full a flame. O Nennius,
Thou hadst a noble uncle knew a Roman,
And how to speak him, how to give him weight
In both his fortunes.

sp.speaker: Bon.
sp.l: By — I think
Ye dote upon these Romans, caratach.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: Witness these wounds, I do; they were fairly given.
I love an enemy: I was born a soldier;
And he that in the head on is troop defies me,
Bending my manly body with his sword,
I make a mistress. Yellow-tressed Hymen
Ne'er tied a longing virgin with more joy,
Than I am married to that man that wounds me:
And are not all these Roman? Ten struck battles
I sucked these honoured scars from, and all Roman:
Ten years of bitter nights and heavy marches,
When many a frozen storm sung thorough my cuirass,
And made it doubtful whether that or I
Were the more stubborn metal, have I wrought thorough,
And all to try these Romans. Ten times a night
I have swom the rivers, when the stars of Rome
Shot at me as I floated, and the billows
Tumbled their watery ruins on my shoulders,
Charging my battered sides with troops of agues;
And still to try these Romans, whom I found
(And if I lie, my wounds be henceforth backward,
And be you witness, gods, and all my dangers)
As ready, and as full of that I brought
(Which was not fear nor flight) as valiant,
As vigilant, as wise, to do and suffer,
Ever advanced as forward as the Britain's,
Their sleeps as short, their hopes as high as ours,
Ay, and as subtle, lady. 't is dishonour,
And, followed, will be impudence, Bonduca,
And grow to no belief, to taint these romance.
Have not I seen the Britain's —

sp.speaker: Bond.
sp.l: What?

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: Dishearted,
Run, run, Bonduca, not the quick rack swifter;
The virgin from the hated ravisher
Not half so fearful? not a flight drawn home,
A round stone from a sling, a lover's wish
Ere made that haste that they have. By —
I have seen these Britain's, that you magnify,
Run as they would have outrun time, and roaring
Basely for mercy, roaring: the light shadows
That in a thought scur o'er the fields of corn,
Halted on crutches to 'em.

sp.speaker: Bon.
sp.l: O ye powers,
What scandals do I suffer?

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: Yes, Bonduca,
I have seen thee run too, and thee, Nennius;
Yea, run apace, both; then when Penyus
The Roman girl cut thorough your armed carts,
And drive 'em headlong on ye down the hill;
Then when he hunted ye, like britain-foxes,
More by the sent then sight: then did I see
These valiant and approved men of Britain,
Like boding owls, creep into tods of ivy,
And hoot their fears to one another nightly.

sp.speaker: Nen.
sp.l: And what did you then, caratach?

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: I fled too,
But not so fast; your jewel had been lost then,
Young Hengo there; he trashed me, Nennius:
For when your fears outrun him, then stepped I,
And in the head of all the Roman fury
Took him, and with my tough belt to my back
I buckled him; behind him, my sure shield;
And than I followed. If I say I fought
Five times in bringing off this bud of Britain,
I lie not, Nennius. Neither had ye heard
Me speak this, or ever seen the child more,
But that the son of virtue, Penyus,
Seeing me steer thorough all these storms of danger,
My helm still in my hand, my sword my prow,
Turned to my so my face, he cried out nobly,
Go, Britain, bear thy lion's whelp off safely;
Thy manly sword has ransomed thee: grow strong,
And let me meet thee once again in arms;
Then if thou standest, thou art mine. I took his offer,
And here I am to honour him.

sp.speaker: Bon.
sp.l: O cousin,
From what a flight of honour hast thou checked me?
What wouldst thou make me, caratach?

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: See, lady,
The noble use of others in our losses;
Does this afflict ye? Had the Romans cried this,
And as we have done theirs, sung out these fortunes,
Railed on our base condition, hooted at us,
Made marks as far as the earth was ours, to show us
Nothing but sea could stop our flights; despised us,
And held it equal whither banqueting
Or beating of the Britain's were more business,
It would have galled ye.

sp.speaker: Bon.
sp.l: Let me think we conquered.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: Do; but so think, as we may be conquered:
And where we have found virtue, though in those
That came to make us slaves, let's cherish it.
There's not a blow we gave since Julius landed,
That was of strength and worth, but like records
They file to after-ages. Our registers,
The Romans, are for noble deeds of honour;
And shall we burn their mentions with upbraidings?

sp.speaker: Bon.
sp.l: No more, I see myself: thou hast made me, cousin,
More than my fortunes durst; for they abused me,
And wound me up so high, I swelled with glory:
Thy temperance has cured that tympany,
And given me health again, nay, more discretion.
Shall we have peace? for now I love these Romans.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: Thy love and hate are both unwise ones, lady.

sp.speaker: Bon.
sp.l: Your reason?

sp.speaker: Nen.
sp.l: Is not peace the end of arms?

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: Not where the cause implies a general conquest:
Had we a difference with some petty isle,
Or with our neighbours (Lady) for our landmarks,
The taking in of some rebellious lord,
Or making a head against commotions,
After a day of blood, peace might be argued:
But where we grapple for the ground we live on,
The liberty we hold as dear as life,
The gods we worship, and next those, our honours,
And with those swords that know no end of battle:
Those men beside themselves allow no neighbour;
Those minds that where the day is claim inheritance,
And where the sun makes ripe the fruits, their harvest,
And where they march, but measure out more ground
To add to Rome, and here i'th' bowels on us;
It must not be; no, as they are our foes,
And those that must be so until we tire 'em,
Let is use the peace of honour, that is fair dealing,
But in our ends, our swords. That hardy Roman
That hopes to graft himself into my stock,
Must first begin his kindred under ground,
And be allied in ashes.

sp.speaker: Bon.
sp.l: Caratach,
As thou hast nobly spoken, shall be done;
And Hengo to thy charge I here deliver:
The Romans shall have worthy wars.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: They shall.
And, little sir, when your young bones grow stiffer,
And when I see ye able in a morning
To beat a dozen boys, and then to breakfast,
I'll tie ye to a sword.

sp.speaker: Heng.
sp.l: And what then, uncle?

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: Then ye must kill, sir, the next valiant Roman
That calls ye knave.

sp.speaker: Hengo.
sp.l: And must I kill but one?

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: An hundred, boy, I hope.

sp.speaker: Hengo.
sp.l: I hope five hundred.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: That is a noble boy. Come, worthy lady,
Let's to our several charges, and henceforth
Allow an enemy both weight and worth. Exeunt.

div.head: Scaena secunda.
div.stage: Enter Junius and Petillius, two Roman captains.

sp.speaker: Petill.
sp.l: What ailst thou, man? dost thou want meat?

sp.speaker: Jun.
sp.l: No.

sp.speaker: Petill.
sp.l: Clothes?

sp.speaker: Jun.
sp.l: Neither. For heaven's love, leave me.

sp.speaker: Petill.
sp.l: Drink?

sp.speaker: Jun.
sp.l: Ye tire me.

sp.speaker: Petill.
sp.l: Come, 't is drink; I know 't is drink.

sp.speaker: Jun.
sp.l: 'T is no drink.

sp.speaker: Petill.
sp.l: I say 't is drink: for what affliction
Can light so heavy on a soldier,
To dry him up as thou art, but no drink?
Thou shalt have drink.

sp.speaker: Jun.
sp.l: Prithee, Petillius —

sp.speaker: Petill.
sp.l: And by mine honour, much drink, valiant drink:
Never tell me, thou shalt have drink. I see,
Like a true friend, into thy wants: 'tis drink;
And when I leave thee to a desolation,
Especially of that dry nature, hang me.

sp.speaker: Jun.
sp.l: Why do you do this to me?

sp.speaker: Petill.
sp.l: For I see ▪
Although your modesty would fain conceal it,
Which sits as sweetly on a soldier,
As an old side-saddle.

sp.speaker: Jun.
sp.l: What do you see?

sp.speaker: Petill.
sp.l: I see as far as day, that thou wantest drink.
Did I not find thee gaping like an oyster
For a new tide? thy very thoughts lie bare
Like a low ebb? thy soul that rid in sack,
Lies moored for want of liquor? Do but see
Into thyself; for by — I do:
For all thy body is chapped, and cracked like timber
For want of moisture: what thou wantest there, Junius,
And if it be not drink.

sp.speaker: Jun.
sp.l: You have too much on 't.

sp.speaker: Petill.
sp.l: It may be a whore too; say it be: come, meecher,
Thou shalt have both: a pretty valiant fellow,
Die for a little lap and lechery?
No, it shall ne'er be said in our country,
Thou didst o'th' chincough. Hear, thou noble Roman,
The son of her that loves a soldier,
Hear what I promised for thee; thus I said,
Lady, I take thy son to my companion,
Lady, I love thy son, thy son loves war,
The war loves danger, danger drink, drink discipline,
Which is society and lechery;
These two beget commanders: fear not, lady,
Thy son shall lead.

sp.speaker: Jun.
sp.l: 'T is a strange thing, Petillius,
That so ridiculous and loose a mirth
Can master your affections.

sp.speaker: Petill.
sp.l: Any mirth,
And any way, of any subject, Junius,
Is better than unmanly mustiness:
What harm's in drink, in a good wholesome wench?
I do beseech ye, sir, what error? yet
It cannot out of my head handsomely,
But thou wouldst fain be drunk: come, no more fooling,
The general has new wine, new come over.

sp.speaker: Jun.
sp.l: He must have new acquaintance for it too,
For I will none, I thank ye.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: None, I thank ye?
A short and touchy answer. None I thank ye:
Ye do not scorn it, do ye?

sp.speaker: Jun.
sp.l: Gods defend sir;
I owe him still more honour.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: None, I thank ye:
No company, no drink, no wench, I thank ye.
Ye shall be worse entreated, sir.

sp.speaker: Jun.
sp.l: Petillius,
As thou art honest, leave me.

sp.speaker: Petill.
sp.l: None, I thank ye;
A modest and a decent resolution,
And well put on. Yes, I will leave ye, Junius,
And leave ye to the boys, that very shortly
Shall all salute ye, by your new surname
Of Junius none I thank ye. I would starve now,
Hang, drown, despair, deserve the forks, lie open
To all the dangerous passes of a wench,
Bound to believe her tears, and wed her aches,
Ere I would own thy follies. I have found ye,
Your lays, and outleaps Junius, haunts, and lodges:
I have viewed ye, and I have found ye by my skill
To be a fool o'th' first head, Junius,
And I will hunt ye: ye are in love, I know it:
Ye are an ass, and all the camp shall know
A peevish idle boy; your dame shall know it;
A wronger of my care; yourself shall know it.

div.stage: Enter corporal Judas, and four soldiers.

sp.speaker: Jud.
sp.l: A bean? A princely diet, a full banquet,
To what we compass.

sp.speaker: 1 soldier
sp.l: Fight like hogs for acorns?

sp.speaker: 2 soldier
sp.l: Venture our lives for pig-nuts?

sp.speaker: Petill.
sp.l: What ail these rascals?

sp.speaker: 3 soldier
sp.l: If this hold, we are starved.

sp.speaker: Jud.
sp.l: For my part, friends,
Which is but twenty beans a day, a hard world
For officers, and men of action;
And those so clipped by master mouse, and rotten:
For understand 'em French beans, where the fruits
Are ripened like the people, in old tubs.
For mine own part, I say, I am starved already,
Not worth another bean, consumed to nothing,
Nothing but flesh and bones left, miserable:
Now if this musty provender can prick me
To honourable matters of achievement, gentlemen,
Why there's the point.

sp.speaker: 4 soldier
sp.l: I'll fight no more.

sp.speaker: Petill.
sp.l: You'll hang then,
A sovereign help for hunger. Ye eating rascals,
Whose gods are beef and brews, whose brave angers
Do execution upon these, and Chibbals:
Ye dogs heads i' th' porridge pot; you fight no more?
Does Rome depend upon your resolution
For eating mouldy piecrust?

sp.speaker: 3 soldier
sp.l: Would we had it.

sp.speaker: Jud.
sp.l: I may do service, captain.

sp.speaker: Petill.
sp.l: In a fishmarket.
You, corporal currycomb, what will your fighting
Profit the commonwealth? do you hope to triumph,
Or dare your vamping valour, good man cobbler,
Clap a new sole to th' kingdom? s'death , ye dog-whelps
You, fight, or not fight.

sp.speaker: Jud.
sp.l: Captain.

sp.speaker: Petill.
sp.l: Out, ye flesh-flies,
Nothing but noise and nastiness.

sp.speaker: Jud.
sp.l: Give us meat,
Whereby we may do.

sp.speaker: Petill.
sp.l: Whereby hangs your valour?

sp.speaker: Jud.
sp.l: Good bits afford good blows.

sp.speaker: Petill.
sp.l: A good position:
How long is 't since thou eatest last? wipe thy mouth,
And then tell truth.

sp.speaker: Jud.
sp.l: I have not eat to th' purpose —

sp.speaker: Petill.
sp.l: To th' purpose? what's that? half a cow, and garlic?
Ye rogues, my company eat turf, and talk not;
Timber they can digest, and fight upon 't;
Old matts, and mud with spoons, rare meats. Your shoes, slaves,
Dare ye cry out of hunger, and those extant?
Suck your sword-hilts, ye slaves, if ye be valiant;
Honour will make 'em marchpane: to the purpose?
A grievous penance. Dost thou see that gentleman,
That melancholy monsieur?

sp.speaker: Jun.
sp.l: Pray ye, Petillius.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: He has not eat these three weeks.

sp.speaker: 2 soldier
sp.l: 'Has drunk the more then.

sp.speaker: 3 soldier
sp.l: And that is all one.

sp.speaker: Petill.
sp.l: Nor drunk nor slept these two months.

sp.speaker: Jud.
sp.p: Captain, we do beseech you as poor soldiers, men that have seen good days, whose mortal stomachs may sometime feel afflictions.

sp.speaker: Jun.
sp.l: This, Petillius,
Is not so nobly done.

sp.speaker: Petill.
sp.l: 'T is common profit;
Urge him to th' point, he will find you out a food
That needs no teeth nor stomach; a strange formity
Will feed ye up as fat as hens i' th' foreheads,
And make ye fight like fichocks, to him.

sp.speaker: Jud.
sp.l: Captain.

sp.speaker: Jun.
sp.l: Do you long to have your throats cut?

sp.speaker: Petill.
sp.l: See what metal
It makes in him: two meals more of this melancholy,
And there lies caratach.

sp.speaker: Jud.
sp.l: We do beseech ye.

sp.speaker: 2 soldier
sp.l: Humbly beseech your valour.

sp.speaker: Jun.
sp.l: Am I only
Become your sport, Petillius?

sp.speaker: Jud.
sp.l: But to render
In way of general good, in preservation.

sp.speaker: Jun.
sp.l: Out of my thoughts, ye slaves.

sp.speaker: 4 soldier
sp.l: Or rather pity.

sp.speaker: 3 soldier
sp.l: Your warlike remedy against the maw-worms.

sp.speaker: Jud.
sp.l: Or notable receipt to live by nothing.

sp.speaker: Petill.
sp.l: Out with your table-books.

sp.speaker: Jun.
sp.l: Is this true friendship?
And must my killing griefs make others may-games?
Stand from my sword's point, slaves; your poor starved spirits
Can make me no oblations; else, oh love,
Thou proudly blind destruction, I would send thee
Whole hecatombs of hearts, to bleed my sorrows.

sp.speaker: Jud.
sp.l: Alas, he lives by love, sir,Exit Junius.

sp.speaker: Petill.
sp.l: So he does, sir,
And cannot you do so too? All my company
Are now in love, ne'er think of meat, nor talk
Of what provant is: ay-mees, and hearty hey-hoes,
Are salads fit for soldiers. Live by meat,
By larding up your bodies? 't is lewd, and lazy,
And shows ye merely mortal, dull, and drives ye
To fight like camels, with baskets at your noses.
Get ye in love; ye can whore well enough,
That all the world knows: fast ye into famine,
Yet ye can crawl like crabs to wenches, handsomely.
Fall but in love now, as ye see example,
And follow it but with all your thoughts, probatum,
There's so much charge saved, and your hungers ended.
Away, I hear the general: get ye in love all,Drum afar off.
Up to the ears in love, that I may hear
No more of these rude murmurings; and discreetly
Carry your stomachs, or I prophesy
'A pickled rope will choke ye. Jog, and talk not. Exeunt.

div.stage: Enter Swetonius, Demetrius, Decius, drum, colours.

sp.speaker: Swet.
sp.l: Demetrius, is the messenger dispatched
To Penyus, to command him to bring up
The volans regiment?

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: He is there by this time.

sp.speaker: Swet.
sp.l: And are the horse well viewed we brought from Mona?

sp.speaker: Dec.
sp.l: The troops are full, and lusty.

sp.speaker: Swet.
sp.l: Good Petillius,
Look to those eating rogues, that bawl for victuals,
And stop their throats a day or two: provision
Waits but the wind to reach us.

sp.speaker: Petill.
sp.l: Sir, already
I have been tampering with their stomachs, which I find
As deaf as adders to delays: your clemency
Hath made their murmurs, mutinies, nay, rebellions:
Now, and they want but mustard, they're in uproars:
No oil but candy, Lucitanian figs,
And wine from Lestos, now can satisfy 'em:
The British waters are grown dull and muddy,
The fruit disgustful: Orontes must be sought for,
And apples from the happy isles: the truth is,
They are more curious now in having nothing,
Then if the sea and land turned up their treasures:
This lost the colonies, and gave Bonduca
(With shame we must record it) time and strength
To look into our fortunes; great discretion
To follow offered victory; and last, full pride
To brave us to our teeth, and scorn our ruins.

sp.speaker: Swet.
sp.l: Nay, chide not, good Petillius, I confess
My will to conquer Mona, and long stay
To execute that will, let in these losses:
All shall be right again, and as a pine
Rent from Oeta by a sweeping tempest,
Jointed again, and made a mast, defies
Those angry winds that split him: so will I,
Pieced to my never-failing strength and fortune,
Steer thorough these swelling dangers, blow their prides up,
And bear like thunder through their loudest tempests:
They keep the field still.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: Confident and full.

sp.speaker: Petill.
sp.l: In such a number, one would swear they grew,
The hills are wooded with their partisans,
And all the valleys overgrown with darts,
As Moors are with rank rushes: no ground left us
To charge upon, no room to strike: say fortune
And our endeavours bring us in to 'em,
They are so infinite, so ever springing,
We shall be killed with killing; of desperate women,
That neither fear, or shame ere found, the devil
Has ranked amongst 'em multitudes: say the men fail,
They will poison us with their petticoats: say they fail,
They have priests enough to pray us into nothing.

sp.speaker: Swet.
sp.l: These are imaginations, dreams of nothings,
The man that doubts or fears.

sp.speaker: Dec.
sp.l: I am free of both.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: The selfsame I.

sp.speaker: Petill.
sp.l: And I as free as any;
As careless of my flesh, of that we call life,
So I may lose it nobly; as indifferent
As if it were my diet. Yet, noble general,
It was a wisdom learned from you; I learned it,
And worthy of a soldier's care, most worthy,
To weigh with most deliberate circumstance
The ends of accidents, above their offers;
How to go on and get, to save a Roman,
Whose one life is more worth in way of doing,
Than millions of these painted wasps; how viewing
To find advantage out; how, found, to follow it
With counsel and discretion, lest mere fortune
Should claim the victory.

sp.speaker: Swet.
sp.l: 'Tis true, Petillius,
And worthily remembered: the rule's certain,
Their uses no less excellent: but where time
Cuts off occasions, danger, time and all
Tend to a present peril, 't is required
Our swords and manhoods be best counsellors,
Our expeditions, presidents. To win, is nothing,
Where reason, time and counsel are our camp-masters:
But there to bear the field, than to be conquerors,
Where pale destruction takes us, takes us beaten,
In wants, and mutinies, ourselves but handfuls,
And to ourselves our own fears, needs a new way,
A sudden and a desperate execution:
Here, how to save, is loss; to be wise, dangerous;
Only a present well-united strength,
And minds made up for all attempts, dispatch it:
Disputing and delay here, cools the courage;
Necessity gives time for doubts; things infinite,
According to the spirit they are preached to,
Rewards like them; and names for after-ages,
Must steel the soldier; his own shame help to arm him;
And having forced his spirit, ere he cools,
Fling him upon his enemies; sudden and swift,
Like tigers amongst foxes, we must fight for 't:
Fury must be our fortune; shame we have lost,
Spurs ever in our sides to prick us forward:
There is no other wisdom nor discretion
Due to this day of ruin, but destruction;
The soldier's order first, and then his anger.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: No doubt they dare redeem all.

sp.speaker: Swet.
sp.l: Then no doubt
The day must needs be ours. That the proud woman
Is infinite in number, better likes me,
Than if we dealt with squadrons: half her army
Shall choke themselves, their own swords dig their graves.
I'll tell ye all my fears, one single valour,
The virtues of the valiant Caratach
More doubts me then all Britain: he's a soldier
So forged out, and so tempered for great fortunes,
So much man thrust into him, so old in dangers,
So fortunate in all attempts, that his mere name
Fights in a thousand men, himself in millions,
To make him roman. But no more. Petillius,
How stands your charge?

sp.speaker: Petill.
sp.l: Ready for all employments,
To be commanded too, sir.

sp.speaker: Swet.
sp.l: 'T is well governed;
Tomorrow we'll draw out, and view the cohorts:
I' th' mean time, all apply their offices.
Where's Junius?

sp.speaker: Petill.
sp.l: In is cabin,
Sick of th' mumps, sir.

sp.speaker: Swet.
sp.l: How?

sp.speaker: Petill.
sp.p: In love, indeed in love, most lamentably loving, to the tune of Queen Dido.

sp.speaker: Dec.
sp.l: Alas poor gentleman.

sp.speaker: Swet.
sp.l: 'T will make him fight the nobler. With what lady?
I'll be a spokesman for him.

sp.speaker: Petill.
sp.l: You'll scant speed, sir.

sp.speaker: Swet.
sp.l: Who is't ?

sp.speaker: Petill.
sp.l: The devil's dam, Bonduca's daughter,
Her youngest, cracked i' th' ring.

sp.speaker: Swet.
sp.l: I am sorry for him:
But sure his own discretion will reclaim him,
He must deserve our anger else. Good captains,
Apply yourselves in all the pleasing forms
Ye can, unto the soldiers; fire their spirits,
And set 'em fit to run this action;
Mine own provision shall be shared amongst 'em,
Till more come in: tell 'em, if now they conquer,
The fat of all the kingdom lies before 'em,
Their shames forgotten, their honours infinite,
And want for ever banished. Two days hence,
Our fortunes, and our swords, and gods be for us. Exeunt.

div.head: Scaena prima.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: I must come?

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: So the general commands, sir.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: I must bring up my regiment?

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: Believe, sir,
I bring no lie.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: But did he say, I must come?

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: So delivered.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: How long is 't, Regulus, since I commanded
In Britain here?

sp.speaker: Reg.
sp.l: About five years, great Penyus.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: The general some five months. Are all my actions
So poor, and lost, my services so barren,
That I 'em remembered in no nobler language
But must come up?

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: I do beseech ye, sir,
Weigh but the time's estate.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: Yes, good lieutenant,
I do, and his that sways it. Must come up?
Am I turned bare centurion? Must, and shall,
Fit embasses to court my honour?

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: Sir —

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: Set me to lead a handful of my men
Against an hundred thousand barbarous slaves
That have marched name by name with Rome's best doers?
Serve 'em up some other meat; I'll bring no food
To stop the jaws of all those hungry wolfs.
My regiment is mine own. I must, my language.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.l: Penyus, where lies the host?

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: Where fate may find 'em.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.l: Are they ingirt?

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: The battle's lost.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.l: So soon?

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: No; but 't is lost, because it must be won:
The Britain's must be victors. Who ere saw
A troop of bloody vultures hovering
About a few corrupted carcases,
Let him behold the silly Roman host,
Girded with millions of fierce Britain swains,
With deaths as many as they have had hopes;
And then go thither, he that loves his shame;
I scorn my life, yet dare not lose my name.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.l: Do not you hold it a most famous end,
When both our names and lives are sacrificed
For Rome's increase?

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: Yes, Curius; but mark this too;
What glory is there, of what lasting fame
Can be to Rome, or us? what full example,
When one is smothered with a multitude,
And crowded in amongst a nameless press?
Honour got out of flint, and on their heads
Whose virtues, like the sun, exhaled all valours,
Must not be lost in mists and fogs of people,
Noteless, and out of name, but rude and naked:
Nor can Rome task us with impossibilities,
Or bid us fight against a flood: we serve her,
That she may proudly say she has good soldiers,
Nor slaves to choke all hazards. Who but fools,
That make no difference betwixt certain dying,
And dying well, would fling their fames and fortunes
Into this britain-gulf, this quicksand-ruin,
That sinking, swallows us? What noble hand
Can find a subject fit for blood there? or what sword
Room for his execution? What air to cool us,
But poisoned with their blasting breathes and curses,
Where we lie buried quick above the ground,
And are with labouring sweat, and breathless pain,
Killed like to slaves, and cannot kill again?

sp.speaker: Dru.
sp.p: Penyus, mark ancient wars, and know that then captains weighed an hundred thousand men.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: Drusius, mark ancient wisdom, and you'll find than
He gave the overthrow that saved his men.
I must not go.

sp.speaker: Reg.
sp.l: The soldiers are desirous,
Their eagles all drawn out, sir.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: Who drew up. Regulus?
Ha? speak: did you? whose bold will durst attempt this?
Drawn out? why, who commands, sir? on whose warrant
Durst they advance?

sp.speaker: Reg.
sp.l: I keep mine own obedience.

sp.speaker: Dru.
sp.p: 'T is like the general cause, their love of honour, relieving of their wants.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: Without my knowledge?
Am I no more? my place but at their pleasures?
Come, who did this?

sp.speaker: Dru.
sp.l: By — sir, I am ignorant.

div.stage: Drum softly within: then enter soldiers with drum and colours.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: What, am I grown a shadow? Hark, they march.
I will know, and will be myself. Stand, disobedience;
He that advances one foot higher, dies for 't.
Run thorough the regiment upon your duties,
And charge 'em on command: beat back again,
By — I'll tith 'em all else.

sp.speaker: Reg.
sp.l: We'll do our best.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: Back; cease your bawling drums there,
I'll beat the tubs about your brains else. Back:
Do I speak with less fear than thunder to ye?
Must I stand to beseech ye? home, home: ha?
Do ye stare upon me? Are those minds I moulded,
Those honest valiant tempers I was proud
To be a fellow to, those great discretions
Made your names feared and honoured, turned to wild-fires?
O gods, to disobedience? Command, farewell;
And be ye witness with me, all things sacred,
I have no share in these men's shames. March, soldiers,
And seek your own sad ruins; your old Penyus
Dares not behold your murders.

sp.speaker: Soldier
sp.l: Captain.

sp.speaker: 2 soldier
sp.l: Captain.

sp.speaker: 3 soldier
sp.l: Dear honoured captain.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: Too too dear loved soldiers,
Which made ye weary of me: and heaven yet knows,
Though in your mutinies, I dare not hate you;
Take your own wills; 't is fit your long experience
Should now know how to rule yourselves: I wrong ye,
In wishing ye to save your lives and credits,
To keep your necks whole from the axe hangs o'er ye:
Alas, I much dishonoured ye: go, seek the Britain's,
And say ye come to glut their sacrifices;
But do not say I sent ye. What ye have been,
How excellent in all parts, good, and governed,
Is only left of my command, for story;
What now ye are, for pity. Fare ye well.

sp.speaker: Dru.
sp.p: O turn again, great Penyus; see the soldier in all points apt for duty.

sp.speaker: Reg.
sp.l: See his sorrow
For his disobedience, which he says was haste,
And haste (He thought) to please you with. See, captain,
The toughness of his courage turned to water;
See how his manly heart melts.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: Go, beat homeward,
There learn to eat your little with obedience,
And henceforth strive to do as I direct ye.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: My answer, sir.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: Tell the great general,
My companies are no faggots to fill breaches;
Myself no man that must, or shall, can carry:
Bid him be wise; and where he is, he is safe then;
And when he finds out possibilities,
He may command me. Commend me to the captains.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: All this I shall deliver.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: Farewell, Macer. Exit Penyus.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.l: Pray gods this breed no mischief.

sp.speaker: Reg.
sp.l: It must needs,
If stout Swetonius win; for then his anger,
Besides the soldier's loss of due, and honour,
Will break together on him.

sp.speaker: Dru.
sp.l: He's a brave fellow;
And but a little hide his haughtiness,
(Which is but sometimes neither, on some causes)
He shows the worthiest Roman this day living.
You may, good Curius, to the general
Make all things seem the best.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.l: I shall endeavour:
Pray for our fortunes, gentlemen. If we fall,
This one farewell serves for a funeral.
The gods make sharp our swords, and steel our hearts;
We dare, alas, but cannot fight our parts.

div.head: Scaena secunda.
div.stage: Enter Junius, Petillius and a herald.

sp.speaker: Petill.
sp.l: Let him go on: stay, now he talks.

sp.speaker: Jun.
sp.l: Why?
Why should I love mine enemy? what is beauty?
Of what strange violence, that like the plague,
It works upon our spirits? blind they feign him,
I am sure, I find it so.

sp.speaker: Petill.
sp.l: A dog shall lead ye.

sp.speaker: Jun.
sp.l: His fond affections blinder.

sp.speaker: Petill.
sp.l: Hold ye there still.

sp.speaker: Jun.
sp.l: It takes away my sleep,

sp.speaker: Petill.
sp.l: Alas, poor chicken.

sp.speaker: Jun.
sp.l: My company, content; almost my fashion.

sp.speaker: Petill.
sp.l: Yes, and your weight too, if you follow it.

sp.speaker: Jun.
sp.p: 'Tis sure the plague, for no man dare come near me without an antidote: 'tis far worse; hell.

sp.speaker: Petill.
sp.l: Thou art damned without redemption then.

sp.speaker: Jun.
sp.l: The way to 't
Strewed with fair western smiles, and April blushes,
Led by the brightest constellations; eyes,
And sweet proportions, envying heaven: but from thence
No way to guide, no path, no wisdom brings us.

sp.speaker: Petill.
sp.l: Yes, a smart water, Junius.

sp.speaker: Jun.
sp.l: Do I fool?
Know all this, and fool still? Do I know further,
That when we have enjoyed our ends, we lose 'em,
And all our appetites are but as dreams
We laugh at in our ages.

sp.speaker: Petil.
sp.l: Sweet philosopher!

sp.speaker: Jun.
sp.l: Do I know on still, and yet know nothing? Mercy gods,
Why am I thus ridiculous?

sp.speaker: Petill.
sp.l: Motley on thee,
Thou art an arrant ass.

sp.speaker: Jun.
sp.l: Can red and white,
An eye, a nose, a cheek,

sp.speaker: Petill.
sp.l: But one cheek, Junius?
An half-faced mistress?

sp.speaker: Jun.
sp.l: With a little trim,
That wanton fools call fashion, thus abuse me?
Take me beyond my reason? Why should not I
Dote on my horse well trapped, my sword well hatched?
They are as handsome things, to me more useful,
And possible to rule too. Did I but love,
Yet 'twere excusable, my youth would bear it;
But to love there, and that no time can give me,
Mine honour dare not ask: she has been ravished
My nature, must not know; she hates our nation.
Thus to dispose my spirit!

sp.speaker: Petill.
sp.l: Stay a little,
He will declaim again.

sp.speaker: Jun.
sp.l: I will not love; I am a man, have reason,
And I will use it: I'll no more tormenting,
Nor whining for a wench, there are a thousand,

sp.speaker: Petill.
sp.l: Hold thee there boy.

sp.speaker: Jun.
sp.l: A thousand will entreat me.

sp.speaker: Petill.
sp.l: Ten thousand, Junius.

sp.speaker: Jun.
sp.l: I am young and lusty,
And to my fashion valiant; can please nightly.

sp.speaker: Petill.
sp.l: I'll swear thy back's probatum, for I have known thee
Leap at sixteen like a strong stallion.

sp.speaker: Jun.
sp.l: I will be man again.

sp.speaker: Petill.
sp.l: Now mark the working,
The devil and the spirit tug for't: twenty pound
Upon the devil's head.

sp.speaker: Jun.
sp.l: I must be wretched.

sp.speaker: Petill.
sp.l: I knew I had won.

sp.speaker: Jun.
sp.l: Nor have I so much power
To shun my fortune.

sp.speaker: Petill.
sp.l: I will hunt thy fortune
With all the shapes imagination breeds,Music.
But I will fright thy devil: stay, he sings now.

div.stage: Song, by Junius, and Petillius after him in mockage.

sp.speaker: Jun.
sp.l: Must I be thus abused?

sp.speaker: Petill.
sp.l: Yes marry must ye.
Let's follow him close: o, there he is, now read it.

sp.speaker: Herald
sp.p: It is the general's command, that all sick, persons old and unable, retire within the trenches; he that fears his liberty, to leave the field: fools, boys, and lovers must not come near the regiments, for fear of their infections; especially those cowards they call lovers.

sp.speaker: Jun.
sp.l: Ha?

sp.speaker: Petill.
sp.l: Read on.

sp.speaker: Herald.
sp.p: If any common soldier love an enemy, he's whipped and made a slave: if any captain; cast, with loss of honours, flung out o'th' army, and made unable ever after to bear the name of a soldier.

sp.speaker: Jun.
sp.p: The — consume ye all, rogues. Exit Jun.

sp.speaker: Petill.
sp.l: Let this work:
Has something now to chew upon: he's gone,
Come, shake no more.

sp.speaker: Herald
sp.l: Well, sir, you may command me,
But not to do the like again for Europe:
I would have given my life for a bent twopence.
If I ere read to lovers whilst I live again,
Or come within their confines —

sp.speaker: Petill.
sp.l: There's your payment,
And keep this private.

sp.speaker: Herald
sp.l: I am schooled for talking. Exit herald.

sp.speaker: Petill.
sp.l: How now, Demetrius, are we drawn?

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: 'Tis doing:
Your company stands fair; but pray ye, where's Junius?
Half his command are wanting, with some forty
That Decius leads.

sp.speaker: Petill.
sp.l: Hunting for victuals:
Upon my life freebooting rogues, their stomachs
Are like a widow's lust, never satisfied.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: I wonder how they dare stir, knowing the enemy
Master of all the country.

sp.speaker: Petill.
sp.l: Resolute hungers
Know neither fears, nor faiths, they tread on ladders,
Ropes, gallows, and overdo all dangers.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: They may be hanged though.

sp.speaker: Petill.
sp.l: There's their joyful supper,
And no doubt they are at it.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: But for heaven's sake,
How does young Junius?

sp.speaker: Petill.
sp.l: Drawing on, poor gentleman.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: What, to his end?

sp.speaker: Petill.
sp.l: To th'end of all flesh: woman.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: This love has made him a stout soldier.

sp.speaker: Petill.
sp.l: O, a great one,
Fit to command young goslings: but what news?

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: I think the messenger's come back from Penyus by this time, let's go know.

sp.speaker: Petill.
sp.l: What will you say now
If he deny to come, and take exceptions
At some half syllable, or sound delivered
With an ill accent, or some style left out?

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: I cannot think he dare.

sp.speaker: Petill.
sp.l: He dare speak treason,
Dare say, what no man dares believe, dares do —
But that's all one: I'll lay you my black armour
To twenty crowns, he comes not.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: Done.

sp.speaker: Petill.
sp.l: You'll pay.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: I will.

sp.speaker: Petill.
sp.l: Then keep thine old use Penyus,
Be stubborn and vain glorious, and I thank thee.
Come let's go pray for six hours: most of us
I fear, will trouble heaven no more: two good blows
Struck home at two commanders of the Britain's,
And my part's done.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: I do not think of dying.

sp.speaker: Petill.
sp.l: 'Tis possible we may live. But Demetrius,
With what strange legs, and arms, and eyes, and noses,
Let carpenters and copper-smiths consider.
If I can keep my heart whole, and my windpipe,
That I may drink yet like a soldier —

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: Come, let's have better thoughts; mine's on your armour.

sp.speaker: Petil.
sp.l: Mine's in your purse, sir: let's go try the wager.

div.head: Scaena tertia.
div.stage: Enter Judas and his four companions (Halters about their necks) Bonduca, her daughters, Nennius following.

sp.speaker: Bon.
sp.l: Come, hang 'em presently.

sp.speaker: Nen.
sp.l: What made your rogueships
Harrying for victuals here? Are we your friends?
Or do you come for spies? tell me directly,
Would you not willingly be hanged now? do not ye long for't?

sp.speaker: Jud.
sp.l: What say ye? shall we hang in this vain? Hang we must,
And 'tis as good to dispatch it merrily,
As pull an arse like dogs to't.

sp.speaker: 1. Soldier
sp.l: Any way,
So it be handsome.

sp.speaker: 3. Soldier
sp.p: I had as lief 'twere toothsome too: but all agree, and I'll not out boys.

sp.speaker: 4. Soldier
sp.l: Let's hang pleasant.

sp.speaker: Jud.
sp.l: Then pleasant be it: captain, the truth is,
We had as lief hang with meat in our mouths,
As ask your pardon empty.

sp.speaker: Bon.
sp.l: These are brave hungers.
What say you to a leg of beef now, sirrah?

sp.speaker: Jud.
sp.l: Bring me acquainted with it, and I'll tell ye.

sp.speaker: Bon.
sp.l: Torment 'em wenches: I must back; then hang 'em.

sp.speaker: Jud.
sp.l: We humbly thank your grace.

sp.speaker: 1. Daugh.
sp.l: The rogues laugh at us.

sp.speaker: 2. Daugh.
sp.l: Sirrah, what think you of a wench now?

sp.speaker: Jud.
sp.l: A wench, lady?
I do beseech your ladyship, retire,
I'll tell ye presently, ye see the time's short;
One crash; even to the setling of my conscience.

sp.speaker: Nen.
sp.l: Why, is't no more but up, boys?

sp.speaker: Jud.
sp.l: Yes, ride too captain.
Will you but see my seat?

sp.speaker: 1. Daugh.
sp.l: Ye shall be set, sir,
Upon a jade shall shake ye.

sp.speaker: Jud.
sp.l: Sheets, good madam,
Will do it ten times better.

sp.speaker: 1. Daugh.
sp.l: Whips, good soldier,
Which ye shall taste before ye hang, to mortify ye;
'Tis pity ye should die thus desperate.

sp.speaker: 2. Daugh.
sp.l: These are the merry Romans, the brave madcaps.
'Tis ten to one we'll cool your resolutions.
Bring out the whips.

sp.speaker: Jud.
sp.l: Would your good ladyships
Would exercise 'em too.

sp.speaker: 4. Soldier
sp.l: Surely ladies,
We'd show you a strange patience.

sp.speaker: Nen.
sp.l: Hang 'em, rascals,
They'll talk thus on the wheel. Enter Caratach.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: Now what's the matter?
What are these fellows? what's the crime committed,
That they wear necklaces?

sp.speaker: Nen.
sp.l: They are Roman rogues,
Taken a foraging.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: Is that all, Nennius?

sp.speaker: Jud.
sp.l: Would I were fairly hanged; this is the devil,
The kill-cow caratach.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: And you would hang 'em.

sp.speaker: Nen.
sp.l: Are they not enemies?

sp.speaker: 1. Soldier
sp.l: My breech makes buttons.

sp.speaker: 1. Daugh.
sp.l: Are they not our tormentors?

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: Tormentors? Flea-traps.
Pluck off your halters, fellows.

sp.speaker: Nen.
sp.l: Take heed, caratach,
Taint not your wisdom.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: Wisdom, Nennius?
Why, who shall fight against us, make our honours,
And give a glorious day into our hands,
If we dispatch our foes thus? what's their offence?
Stealing a loaf or two to keep out hunger,
A piece of greasy bacon, or a pudding?
Do these deserve the gallows? They are hungry,
Poor hungry knaves, no meat at home left, starved:
Art thou not hungry?

sp.speaker: Jud.
sp.l: Monstrous hungry.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: He looks like hunger's self: get 'em some victuals, and wine to cheer their hearts, quick: hang up poor pilchers?

sp.speaker: 2. Soldier
sp.l: This is the bravest captain —

sp.speaker: Nen.
sp.l: Caratach,
I'll leave you to your will.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: I'll answer all, sir.

sp.speaker: 2. Daugh.
sp.l: Let's up, and view his entertainment of 'em.
I am glad they are shifted any way, their tongues else
Would still have murdered us.

sp.speaker: 1. Daugh.
sp.l: Let's up, and see it. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: Sit down poor knaves: why, where's this wine
And victuals?
Who waits there?

sp.speaker: Suit. within.
sp.l: Sir, 'tis coming.

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.l: Who are these uncle?

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: They are Romans, boy.

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.l: Are these they
That vex mine aunt so? can these fight? they look
Like empty scabbards, all, no mettle in 'em,
Like men of clouts, set to keep crows from orchards;
Why, I dare fight with these.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: That's my good chicken. And how do ye?
How do you feel your stomachs?

sp.speaker: Jud.
sp.l: Wondrous apt, sir,
As shall appear when time calls.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: That's well, down with't,
A little grace will serve your turns: eat softly,
You'll choke ye knaves else: give 'em wine.

sp.speaker: Jud.
sp.l: Not yet, sir,
We're even a little busy.

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.l: Can that fellow
Do any thing but eat? thou fellow.

sp.speaker: Jud.
sp.l: Away boy,
Away, this is no boys play.

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.l: By —, uncle,
If his valour lie in's teeth, he's the most valiant.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: I am glad to hear ye talk, sir.

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.l: Good uncle tell me,
What's the price of a couple of crammed Romans?

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: Some twenty Britain's boy; these are good soldiers,

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.l: Do not the cowards eat hard too?

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: No more, boy.
Come, I'll sit with you too; sit down by me, boy.

sp.speaker: Jud.
sp.l: Pray bring your dish then.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: Hearty knaves: more meat there.

sp.speaker: 1. Soldier
sp.l: That's a good hearing.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: Stay now and pledge me.

sp.speaker: Jud.
sp.l: This little piece sir.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: By — square eaters,
More meat I say: upon my conscience
The poor rogues have not eat this month: how terribly
They charge upon their victuals: dare ye fight thus?

sp.speaker: Jud.
sp.l: Believe it sir, like devils.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: Well said famine,
Here's to thy general.

sp.speaker: Jud.
sp.l: Most excellent captain, I will now pledge thee.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: And tomorrow night, say to him,
His head is mine.

sp.speaker: Jud.
sp.l: I can assure ye captain,
He will not give it for this washing.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: Well said. Daughters above.

sp.speaker: 1. Daugh.
sp.l: Here's a strange entertainment: how the thieves drink.

sp.speaker: 2. Daug.
sp.l: Danger is dry, they looked for colder liquor.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: Fill 'em more wine, give 'em full bowls; which of you all now
In recompense of this good, dare but give me
A sound knock in the battle?

sp.speaker: Jud.
sp.l: Delicate captain,
To do thee a sufficient recompense,
I'll knock thy brains out.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: Do it.

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.l: Thou dar'st as well be damned: thou knock his brains out,
Thou skin of man? Uncle, I will not hear this.

sp.speaker: Jud.
sp.l: Tie up your whelp.

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.l: Thou kill my uncle?
Would I had but a sword for thy sake, thou dried dog.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: What a mettle
This little vermin caries.

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.l: Kill mine uncle?

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: He shall not, child.

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.l: He cannot: he's a rogue,
An only eating rogue: kill my sweet uncle?
O that I were a man.

sp.speaker: Jud.
sp.l: By this wine,
Which I will drink to captain Junius,
Who loves the Queen's most excellent majesty's little daughter
Most sweetly, and most fearfully, I will do it.

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.l: Uncle, I'll kill him with a great pin.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: No more, boy.
I'll pledge thy captain: to ye all, good fellows.

sp.speaker: 2. Daugh.
sp.l: In love with me? that love shall cost your lives all:
Come sister, and advise me; I have here
A way to make an easy conquest of 'em,
If fortune favour me.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: Let's see ye sweat
Tomorrow, blood and spirit, boys, this wine
Turned to stern valour.

sp.speaker: 1. Soldier
sp.l: Hark ye Judas,
If he should hang us after all this.

sp.speaker: Jud.
sp.l: Let him:
I'll hang like a gentleman, and a roman.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: Take away there,
They have enough.

sp.speaker: Jud.
sp.l: Captain, we thank you heartily
For your good cheer, and if we meet tomorrow,
One of us pays for't.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: Get 'em guides, their wineEnter 2d daughter and a servant.
Has over mastered 'em.

sp.speaker: 2. Daugh.
sp.l: That hungry fellow
With the red beard there, give it him, and this,
To see it well delivered.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: Farewell, knaves;
Speak nobly of us, keep your words tomorrow,
And do something worthy your meat. Go, guide 'em,
And see 'em fairly onward.

sp.speaker: Jud.
sp.l: Meaning me, sir?

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.l: The same.
The youngest daughter to the Queen entreats ye
To give this privately to captain Junius,
This for your pains.

sp.speaker: Jud.
sp.l: I rest her humble servant.
Commend me to thy lady. Keep your files, boys.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.l: I must instruct ye farther.

sp.speaker: Jud.
sp.l: Keep your files there.
Order, sweet friends: faces about now.

sp.speaker: Guide.
sp.l: Here sir,
Here lies your way.

sp.speaker: Jud.
sp.l: 'Bless the founders, I say.
Fairly, good soldiers, fairly march now: close, boys.

div.head: Scaena quarta.
div.stage: Enter Swetonius, Petillius, Demetrius, Decius, Macer.

sp.speaker: Swet.
sp.l: Bid me be wise, and keep me where I am,
And so be safe: not come, because commanded;
Was it not thus?

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: It was, sir.

sp.speaker: Petill.
sp.l: What now think ye?

sp.speaker: Swet.
sp.p: Must come, so heinous to him, so distasteful?

sp.speaker: Petill.
sp.l: Give me my money.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: I confess 'tis due sir,
And presently I'll pay it.

sp.speaker: Swet.
sp.l: His obedience
So blind at his years and experience,
It cannot find where to be tendered?

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: Sir,
The regiment was willing, and advanced too,
The captains at all points steeled up; their preparations
Full of resolve, and confidence; youth and fire,
Like the fair breaking of a glorious day,
Guilded their phalanx: when the angry Penyus
Stepped like a stormy cloud 'twixt them and hopes.

sp.speaker: Swet.
sp.l: And stopped their resolutions?

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: True: his reason
To them was odds, and odds so infinite,
Discretion durst not look upon.

sp.speaker: Swet.
sp.l: Well Penyus,
I cannot think thee coward yet; and treacherous
I dare not think: thou hast lopped a limb off from me,
And let it be thy glory, thou wast stubborn,
Thy wisdom, that thou leftest thy general naked:
Yet ere the sun set, I shall make thee see,
All valour dwells not in thee; all command
In one experience. Thou wilt too late repent this,
And wish, I must come up, had been thy blessing.

sp.speaker: Petill.
sp.l: Let's force him.

sp.speaker: Swet.
sp.l: No, by no means; he's a torrent
We cannot easily stem.

sp.speaker: Petill.
sp.l: I think, a traitor.

sp.speaker: Swet.
sp.l: No ill words: let his own shame first revile him.
That wine I have, see it (Demetrius)
Distributed amongst the soldiers,
To make 'em high and lusty: when that's done,
Petillius, give the word through, that the eagles
May presently advance: no man discover,
Upon his life, the enemies full strength,
But make it of no value: Decius,
Are your starved people yet come home?

sp.speaker: Dec.
sp.l: I hope so.

sp.speaker: Swet.
sp.l: Keep 'em in more obedience: this is no time
To chide, I could be angry else, and say more to ye:
But come, let's order all: whose sword is sharpest,
And valour equal to his sword this day,
Shall be my saint.

sp.speaker: Petill.
sp.l: We shall be holy all then. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Jud.
sp.l: Captain, captain, I have brought 'em off again;
The drunkenest slaves.

sp.speaker: Dec.
sp.l: — confound your rogueships;
I'll call the general, and have ye hanged all.

sp.speaker: Jud.
sp.l: Pray who will you command then?

sp.speaker: Dec.
sp.l: For you, sirrah,
That are the ringleader to these devices,
Whose maw is never crammed, I'll have an engine.

sp.speaker: Jud.
sp.l: A wench, sweet captain.

sp.speaker: Dec.
sp.l: Sweet Judas, even the forks.
Where ye shall have two lictors with two whips
Hammer your hide.

sp.speaker: Jud.
sp.l: Captain, good words, fair words,
Sweet words, good captain; if you like not us,
Farewell, we have employment.

sp.speaker: Dec.
sp.l: Where hast thou been?

sp.speaker: Jud.
sp.l: There where you dare not be with all your valour.

sp.speaker: Dec.
sp.l: Where's that?

sp.speaker: Jud.
sp.l: With the best goodfellow living.

sp.speaker: 1 soldier
sp.l: The King of all good-fellows.

sp.speaker: Dec.
sp.l: Who's that?

sp.speaker: Jud.
sp.l: Caratach.
Shake now, and say, we have done something worthy,
Mark me; with caratach: by this — Caratach:
Do you as much now and you dare: sweet Caratach.
Ye talk of a good fellow, of true drinking;
Well, go thy ways, old Caratach: besides the drink captain,
The bravest running banquet of black puddings,
Pieces of glorious beef.

sp.speaker: Dec.
sp.l: How scaped ye hanging?

sp.speaker: Jud.
sp.l: Hanging's a dog's death: we are gentlemen,
And I say still, old Caratach.

sp.speaker: Dec.
sp.l: Belike then,
You are turned rebels all.

sp.speaker: Jud.
sp.l: We are Roman boys all,
And boys of mettle: I must do that captain,
This day, this very day.

sp.speaker: Dec.
sp.l: Away, ye rascal.

sp.speaker: Jud.
sp.l: Fair words, I say again.

sp.speaker: Dec.
sp.l: What must you do, sir?

sp.speaker: Jud.
sp.l: I must do that my heartstrings yern to do:
But my word's passed.

sp.speaker: Dec.
sp.l: What is it?

sp.speaker: Jud.
sp.l: Why, kill Caratach.
That's all he asked us for our entertainment.

sp.speaker: Dec.
sp.l: More than you'll pay.

sp.speaker: Jud.
sp.l: Would I had sold myself
Unto the skin, I had not promised it:
For such another Caratach.

sp.speaker: Dec.
sp.l: Come fool,
Have ye done your country service?

sp.speaker: Jud.
sp.l: I have brought that
To captain Junius.

sp.speaker: Dec.
sp.l: How?

sp.speaker: Jud.
sp.l: I think will do all:
I cannot tell, I think so.

sp.speaker: Dec.
sp.l: How? to Junius?
I'll more inquire of this: you'll fight now?

sp.speaker: Jud.
sp.l: Promise:
Take heed of promise, captain.

sp.speaker: Dec.
sp.l: Away, and rank then.

sp.speaker: Jud.
sp.l: But hark ye captain, there is wine distributing,
I would fain know what share I have.

sp.speaker: Dec.
sp.l: Be gone,
Ye have too much.

sp.speaker: Jud.
sp.l: Captain, no wine, no fighting.
There's one called Caratach, that has wine.

sp.speaker: Dec.
sp.l: Well sir,
If you'll be ruled now, and do well.

sp.speaker: Jud.
sp.l: Do excellent.

sp.speaker: Dec.
sp.l: Ye shall have wine, or any thing: go file;
I'll see ye have your share: drag out your dormice,
And stow 'em somewhere, where they may sleep handsomely,
They'll hear a hunt's up shortly.

sp.speaker: Jud.
sp.l: Now I love thee:
But no more forks nor whips.

sp.speaker: Dec.
sp.l: Deserve 'em not then:
Up with your men, I'll meet ye presently;
And get 'em sober quickly.

sp.speaker: Jud.
sp.l: Arm, arm, bullies;
All's right again and straight; and which is more,
More wine, more wine: awake ye men of Memphis,
Be sober and discreet, we have much to do boys. Exeunt.

div.head: Scaena prima.

sp.speaker: Messenger
sp.l: Prepare there for the sacrifice, the Queen comes.

div.stage: Enter in solemnity, the Druids singing, the second daughter strewing flowers: then Bonduca, Caratach, Nennius, and others.

sp.speaker: Bond.
sp.l: Ye powerful gods of Britain, hear our prayers;
Hear us you great revengers, and this day
Take pity from our swords, doubt from our valours,
Double the sad remembrance of our wrongs
In every breast; the vengeance due to those
Make infinite and endless: on our pikes
This day pale terror sit, horrors and ruins
Upon our executions; claps of thunder
Hang on our armed carts, and 'fore our troops
Despair and death; shame beyond these attend 'em.
Rise from the dust, ye relics of the dead,
Whose noble deeds our holy druids sing,
O rise, ye valiant bones, let not base earth
Oppress your honours, whilst the pride of Rome
Treads on your stocks, and wipes out all your storeys.

sp.speaker: Nen.
sp.l: Thou great Tiranes, whom our sacred priests,
Armed with dreadful thunder, place on high
Above the rest of the immortal gods,
Send thy consuming fires and deadly bolts,
And shoot 'em home; stick in each Roman heart
A fear fit for confusion; blast their spirits,
Dwell in 'em to destruction; thorough their phalanx
Strike, as thou strikest a proud tree; shake their bodies,
Make their strengths totter, and their topless fortunes
Unroot, and reel to ruin.

sp.speaker: 1. Daugh.
sp.l: O thou god,
Thou feared god, if ever to thy justice
Insulting wrongs, and ravishments of women,
Women derived from thee, their shames, the sufferings
Of those that daily filled thy sacrifice
With virgin incense, have access, now hear me,
Now snatch thy thunder up, now on these Romans,
Despisers of thy power, of us defacers,
Revenge thyself: take to thy killing anger,
To make thy great work full, thy justice spoken,
An utter rooting from this blessed isle
Of what Rome is or has been.

sp.speaker: Bon.
sp.l: Give more incense,
The gods are deaf and drowsy; no happy flame
Rises to raise our thoughts: pour on.

sp.speaker: 2. Daugh.
sp.l: See heaven,
And all you powers that guide us, see, and shame
We kneel so long for pity over your altars;
Since 'tis no light oblation that you look for,
No incense offering, will I hang mine eyes;
And as I wear these stones with hourly weeping,
So will I melt your powers into compassion.
This tear for Prosutagus my brave father,
Ye gods, now think on Rome; this for my mother,
And all her miseries; yet see, and save us:
But now ye must be open eyed. See, heaven,
Oh see thy showers stolen from thee; our dishonours,
O sister, our dishonours: can ye be gods,
And these sins smothered?

sp.speaker: Bon.
sp.l: The fire takes.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: It does so,
But no flame rises. Cease your fretful prayers,
Your whinings, and your tame petitions;
The gods love courage armed with confidence,
And prayers fit to pull them down: weak tears
And troubled hearts, the dull twins of cold spirits,
They sit and smile at. Hear how I salute 'em:
Divine Audate, thou who holdest the reins
Of furious battles, and disordered war,
And proudly rollest thy swarthy chariot wheels
Over the heaps of wounds, and carcases,
Sailing through seas of blood; thou sure-steeled sternness,
Give us this day good hearts, good enemies,
Good blows of both sides, wounds that fear or flight
Can claim no share in; steel us both with angers,
And warlike executions fit thy viewing;
Let Rome put on her best strength, and thy Britain,
Thy little Britain, but as great in fortune,
Meet her as strong as she, as proud, as daring;
And then look on, thou red eyed god: who does best,
Reward with honour; who despair makes fly,
Unarm for ever, and brand with infamy:
Grant this, divine Audate, 't is but justice;
And my first blow thus on thy holy altarA flame arises.
I sacrifice unto thee.

sp.speaker: Bon.
sp.l: It flames out. Music.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: Now sing ye Druides. Song.

sp.speaker: Bon.
sp.l: 'Tis out again.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: Has given us leave to fight yet; we ask no more,
The rest hangs in our resolutions:
Tempt him no more.

sp.speaker: Bon.
sp.l: I would know further cousin,

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: His hidden meaning dwells in our endeavours;
Our valours are our best gods. Cheer the soldier,
And let him eat.

sp.speaker: Messenger
sp.l: He's at it, sir.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: Away then;
When he has done, let's march. Come, fear not lady,
This day the Roman gains no more ground here,
But what his body lies in.

sp.speaker: Bond.
sp.l: Now I am confident. Exeunt.

div.head: Scaena secunda.

sp.speaker: Dec.
sp.l: We dare not hazard it: beside our lives,
It forfeits all our understandings.

sp.speaker: Jun.
sp.l: Gentlemen,
Can ye forsake me in so just a service,
A service for the commonwealth, for honour?
Read but the letter; you may love too.

sp.speaker: Dec.
sp.l: Read it:
If there be any safety in the circumstance,
Or likelihood 'tis love, we will not fail ye.
Read it good Curius.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.l: Willingly.

sp.speaker: Jun.
sp.l: Now mark it.

sp.speaker: Cur. reads.
sp.l: Health to thy heart, my honoured Junius,
And all thy love requited: I am thine,
Thine everlastingly, thy love has won me,
And let it breed no doubt; our new acquaintance
Compels this, 'tis the god's decree to bless us.
The times are dangerous to meet; yet fail not,
By all the love thou bearest me I conjure thee,
Without distrust of danger, to come to me,
For I have purposed a delivery
Both of myself and fortune this blessed day
Into thy hands, if thou thinkst good: to show thee
How infinite my love is, even my mother
Shall be thy prisoner, the day yours without hazard;
For I beheld your danger like a lover,
A just affecter of thy faith: thy goodness,
I know, will use us nobly, and our marriage,
If not redeem, yet lessen Rome's ambition.
I am weary of these miseries: use my mother,
(If you intend to take her) with all honour,
And let this disobedience to my parents
Be laid on love, not me. Bring with thee, Junius,
Spirits resolved to fetch me off, the noblest,
Forty will serve the turn; just at the joining
Of both the battles, we will be weakly guarded;
And for a guide, within this hour shall reach thee
A faithful friend of mine: the gods, my Junius,
Keep thee, and me to serve thee: young Bonvica.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.l: This letter carries much belief, and most objections
Answered, we must have doubted.

sp.speaker: Dec.
sp.l: Is that fellow
Come to ye for a guide yet?

sp.speaker: Jun.
sp.l: Yes.

sp.speaker: Dec.
sp.l: And examined?

sp.speaker: Jun.
sp.l: Far more than that; he has felt tortures, yet
He vows he knows no more than this truth.

sp.speaker: Dec.
sp.l: Strange.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.l: If she mean what she writes, as 't may be probable,
'Twill be the happiest vantage we can lean to.

sp.speaker: Jun.
sp.l: I'll pawn my soul she means truth.

sp.speaker: Dec.
sp.l: Think an hour more,
Than if your confidence grow stronger on ye,
We'll set in with ye.

sp.speaker: Jun.
sp.l: Nobly done; I thank ye;
Ye know the time.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.l: We will be either ready
To give ye present counsel, or join with ye.

div.stage: Enter Swetonius, Petillius, and Demetrius, Macer.

sp.speaker: Jun.
sp.l: No more as ye are gentlemen. The general.

sp.speaker: Swet.
sp.l: Draw out a pace, the enemy waits for us;
Are ye all ready?

sp.speaker: Jun.
sp.l: All our troops attend, sir.

sp.speaker: Swet.
sp.l: I am glad to hear you say so, Junius.
I hope ye are dispossessed.

sp.speaker: Jun.
sp.l: I hope so too, sir.

sp.speaker: Swet.
sp.l: Continue so. And gentlemen, to you now;
To bid you fight is needless, ye are Romans,
The name will fight itself; to tell ye who
You go to fight against, his power, and nature,
But loss of time: ye know it, know it poor,
And oft have made it so. To tell ye further,
His body shows more dreadful than it has done,
To him that fears, less possible to deal with,
Is but to stick more honour on your actions,
Load ye with virtuous names, and to your memories
Tie never dying time, and fortune constant.
Go on in full assurance, draw your swords
As daring and as confident as justice;
The gods of Rome fight for ye; loud fame calls ye,
Pitched on the topless Perinine, and blows
To all the under world: all nations,
The seas, and unfrequented deserts, where the snow dwells,
Wakens the ruined monuments, and there
Where nothing but eternal death and sleep is,
Informs again the dead bones. With your virtues,
Go on, I say, valiant and wise, rule heaven,
And all the great aspects attend 'em. Do but blow
Upon this enemy, who, but that we want foes,
Cannot deserve that name; and like a mist,
A lazy fog, before your burning valours
You'll find him fly to nothing. This is all,
We have swords, and are the sons of ancient Romans,
Heirs to their endless valours, fight and conquer.

sp.speaker: De. Dem.
sp.l: 'Tis done.

sp.speaker: Petill.
sp.l: That man that loves not this day,
And hugs not in his arms the noble danger,
May he die fameless and forgotten.

sp.speaker: Swet.
sp.l: Sufficient,
Up to your troops, and let your drums beat thunder,
March close, and sudden like a tempest: all executions
Done without sparkling of the body: keep your phalanx
Sure lined, and pieced together; your pikes forward,
And so march like a moving fort: ere this day run,
We shall have ground to add to Rome, well won. Exeunt.

div.head: Scaena tertia.

sp.speaker: Nen.
sp.l: The roman is advanced from yond 'Hills brow,
We may behold him, caratach. A march.

div.stage: Drums within at one place afar off.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: Let's thither,
I see the dust fly. Now I see the body,
Observe 'em, Nennius; by — a handsome body,
And of a few, strongly and wisely jointed
Swetonius is a soldier.

sp.speaker: Nen.
sp.l: As I take it,
That's he that gallops by the regiments,
Viewing their preparations.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: Very likely,
He shows no less than general: see how bravely
The body moves, and in the head how proudly
The captain's stick like plumes: he comes apace on;
Good Nennius go, and bid my stout lieutenant
Bring on the first square body to oppose 'em,
And as he charges, open to enclose 'em:
The Queen move next with hers, and wheel about,
To gain their backs, in which I'll lead the vanguard.
We shall have bloody crowns this day, I see by 't;
Haste thee good Nennius, I'll follow instantly.
How close they march, as if they grew together? March.
No place but lined alike: sure from oppression;
They will not change this figure: we must charge 'em,
And charge 'em home at both ends, van and rear,
sp.stage: Drums in another place afar off.
sp.l: They never totter else. I hear our music,
And must attend it: hold good sword, but this day,
And bite hard where I hound thee, and hereafter
I'll make a relic of thee, for young soldiers
To come like pilgrims to, and kiss for conquests.

div.head: Scaena quarta.

sp.speaker: Jun.
sp.l: Now is the time, the fellow stays.

sp.speaker: Dec.
sp.l: What think ye?

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.l: I think 'tis true.

sp.speaker: Jun.
sp.l: Alas, if 'twere a question,
If any doubt or hazard fell into 't,
Do ye think mine own discretion so self-blind,
My care of you so naked, to run headlong?

sp.speaker: Dec.
sp.l: Let's take Petillius with us.

sp.speaker: Jun.
sp.l: By no means:
He's never wise but to himself, nor courteous,
But where the end's his own: we are strong enough,
If not too many. Behind yonder hill
The fellow tells me she attends, weak guarded,
Her mother and her sister.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.l: I would venture.

sp.speaker: Jun.
sp.l: We shall not strike five blows for't: weigh the good,
The general good may come.

sp.speaker: Dec.
sp.l: Away, I'll with ye,
But with what doubt?

sp.speaker: Jun.
sp.l: Fear not, my soul for all. Exeunt.

div.stage: Alarms, drums and trumpets in several places afar off, as at a main battle.

div.head: Scaena quinta.

sp.speaker: Dru.
sp.l: Here ye may see 'em all, sir; from this hill
The country shows off level.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: Gods defend me,
What multitudes they are, what infinites?
The Roman power shows like a little star
Hedged with a double halo. Now the knell rings,
Hark how they shout to th' battle; how the air
Totters and reels, and rends apieces, Drusus,
With the huge volleied clamours.

sp.speaker: Dru.
sp.l: Now they charge.
O gods, of all sides, fearfully.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: Little Rome,
Stand but this growing Hydra one short hour,
And thou hast outdone Hercules.

sp.speaker: Dru.
sp.l: The dust hides 'em,
We cannot see what follows.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: They are gone,
Gone, swallowed, Drusus; this eternal sun
Shall never see 'em march more.

sp.speaker: Dru.
sp.l: O turn this way,
And see a model of the field, some forty,
Against four hundred.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: Well fought, bravely followed;
Oh nobly charged again, charged home too: Drusus,
They seem to carry it: now they charge all,Loud.
Close, close, I say; they follow it: ye gods,
Can there be more in men? more daring spirits?
Still they make good their fortunes. Now they are gone too,
For ever gone: see Drusus, at their backs
A fearful ambush rises. Farewell valours,
Excellent valours: oh Rome, where's thy wisdom?

sp.speaker: Dru.
sp.l: They are gone indeed, sir.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: Look out towards the army,
I am heavy with these slaughters.

sp.speaker: Dru.
sp.l: 'Tis the same still,
Covered with dust and fury. Enter the two daughters, with Junius, Curius, Decius, and soldiers.

sp.speaker: 2. Daugh.
sp.l: Bring 'em in,
Tie 'em, and then unarm 'em.

sp.speaker: 1. Daugh.
sp.l: Valiant Romans,
Ye are welcome to your loves,

sp.speaker: 2. Daugh.
sp.l: Your death, fools.

sp.speaker: Dec.
sp.l: We deserve 'em,
And women do your worst.

sp.speaker: 1. Daug.
sp.l: Ye need not beg it.

sp.speaker: 2. Daug.
sp.l: Which is kind Junius?

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.l: This.

sp.speaker: 2 Dau.
sp.l: Are you my sweet heart?
It looks ill on't: how long is 't, pretty soul,
Since you and I first loved? Had we not reason
To dote extremely upon one another?
How does my love? this is not he: my chicken
Could prate finely, sing a love-song.

sp.speaker: Jun.
sp.l: Monster.

sp.speaker: 2. Daugh.
sp.l: O, now it courts.

sp.speaker: Jun.
sp.l: Armed with more malice
Than he that got thee has the devil.

sp.speaker: 2. Daugh.
sp.l: Good.
Proceed, sweet chick.

sp.speaker: Jun.
sp.l: I hate thee, that's my last.

sp.speaker: 2. Daug.
sp.l: Nay, and ye love me, forward: no? Come sister,
Let's prick our answers on our arrows points,
And make 'em laugh a little. Ye damned lechers,
Ye proud improvident fools, have we now caught ye?
Are ye i'th' noose? Since ye are such loving creatures,
We'll be your Cupids: do ye see these arrows?
We'll send 'em to your wanton livers, goats.

sp.speaker: 1. Dau.
sp.l: O how I'll trample on your hearts, ye villains,
Ambitious salt-itched slaves: Rome's master sins,
The mountain rams topped your hot mothers.

sp.speaker: 2. Daugh.
sp.l: Dogs,
To whose brave founders a salt whore gave suck;
Thieves, honours hangmen, do ye grin? perdition
Take me for ever, if in my fell anger,Enter Caratach.
I do not outdo all example.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: Where,
Where are these ladies? ye keep noble quarter,
Your mother thinks ye dead or taken; upon which,
She will not move her battle. Sure these faces
I have beheld and known, they are Roman leaders,
How came they here?

sp.speaker: 2. Daugh.
sp.l: A trick sir, that we used,
A certain policy conducted 'em
Unto our snare: we have done ye no small service;
These used as we intend, we are for th' battle.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: As you intend? taken by treachery?

sp.speaker: 1. Daugh.
sp.l: Is't not allowed?

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: Those that should gild our conquest,
Make up a battle worthy of our winning,
Catched up by craft?

sp.speaker: 2. Daugh.
sp.l: By any means that's lawful.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: A woman's wisdom in our triumphs? Out,
Out ye sluts, ye follies; from our swords
Filch our revenges basely? Arm again, gentlemen:
Soldiers, I charge ye help 'em.

sp.speaker: 2. Daugh.
sp.l: By — uncle,
We will have vengeance for our rapes.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: By —
You should have kept your legs close then: dispatch there.

sp.speaker: 1. Daugh.
sp.l: I will not off thus.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: He that stirs to execute,
Or she, though it be yourselves, by him that got me,
Shall quickly feel mine anger: one great day given us,
Not to be snatched out of our hands but basely;
And must we shame the gods from whence we have it,
With setting snares for soldiers? I'll run away first,
Be hooted at, and children call me coward,
Before I set up scales for victories:
Give 'em their swords.

sp.speaker: 2. Daug.
sp.l: O gods.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: Bear off the women
Unto their mother.

sp.speaker: 2. Daug.
sp.l: One shot, gentle uncle.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: One cut her fiddlestring: beat 'em off I say.

sp.speaker: 1. Dau.
sp.l: The — take this fortune.

sp.speaker: Cara.
sp.l: Learn to spin,
And curse your knotted hemp: go gentlemen,
Safely go off, up to your troops: be wiser,
There thank me like tall soldiers: I shall seek ye.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.l: A noble worth.

sp.speaker: Dec.
sp.l: Well Junius.

sp.speaker: Jun.
sp.l: Pray ye no more.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.l: He blushes, do not load him.

sp.speaker: Dec.
sp.l: Where's your love now? Drums loud again.

sp.speaker: Jun.
sp.l: Puff, there it flies: come, let's redeem our follies.

sp.speaker: Dru.
sp.l: Awake, sir; yet the Roman body's whole,
I see 'em clear again.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: Whole? 'tis not possible:
Drusus, they must be lost.

sp.speaker: Dru.
sp.l: By — they are whole, sir,
And in brave doing; see, they wheel about
To gain more ground.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: But see there Drusus, see,
See that huge battle moving from the mountains,
Their gilt coats shine like dragon's scales, their march
Like a rough tumbling storm; see them, and view 'em,
And then see Rome no more: say they fail; look,
Look where the armed carts stand; a new army:
Look how they hang like falling rocks, as murdering
Death rides in triumph Drusus: fell destruction
Lashes his fiery horse, and round about him
His many thousand ways to let out souls.
Move me again when they charge, when the mountain
Melts under their hot wheels, and from their axletrees
Huge claps of thunder plough the ground before 'em,
Till then I'll dream what Rome was.

sp.speaker: Swet.
sp.l: O bravely fought; honour till now never showed
Her golden face i'th' field. Like lions, gentlemen,
Y' have held your heads up this day: where's young Junius,
Curius, and Decius?

sp.speaker: Petill.
sp.l: Gone to heaven, I think, sir.

sp.speaker: Sw.
sp.l: Their worths go with 'em: breathe a while: how do ye?

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: Well; some few scurvy wounds, my heart's whole yet.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: Would they would give us more ground.

sp.speaker: Swet.
sp.l: Give? we'll have it.

sp.speaker: Petill.
sp.l: Have it? and hold it too, despite the devil.

sp.speaker: Jun.
sp.p: Lead up to th' head, and line sure: the Qs. Battle begins to charge like wildfire: where's the general?

sp.speaker: Swet.
sp.l: O, they are living yet. Come, my brave soldiers,
Come, let me power Rome's blessing on ye; live,
Live, and lead armies all: ye bleed hard.

sp.speaker: Jun.
sp.l: Best:
We shall appear the sterner to the foe.

sp.speaker: Dec.
sp.l: More wounds, more honour.

sp.speaker: Petill.
sp.l: Lose no time.

sp.speaker: Swet.
sp.l: Away then,
And stand this shock, ye have stood the world.

sp.speaker: Petill.
sp.l: We'll grow to't.
Is not this better now then lousy loving?

sp.speaker: Jun.
sp.l: I am myself, Petillius.

sp.speaker: Petill.
sp.l: 'Tis I love thee. Exeunt Romans.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Charge 'em i'th' flanks: oh ye have played the fool, the fool extremely, the mad fool.

sp.speaker: Bon.
sp.l: Why cousin?

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: The woman fool. Why did you give the word
Unto the carts to charge down, and our people
In gross before the enemy? we pay for't,
Our own swords cut our throats: why? — on't,
Why do you offer to command? the devil,
The devil, and his dam too, who bid you
Meddle in men's affairs? Exeunt Queen, etc.

sp.speaker: Bond.
sp.l: I'll help all.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: Home,
Home and spin woman, spin, go spin, ye trifle.
Open before there, or all's ruin. How,Shouts within.
Now comes the tempest; on ourselves, by —
O woman, scurvy woman, beastly woman. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Dru.
sp.l: Victoria, Victoria.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: How's that, Drusus?

sp.speaker: Dru.
sp.p: They win, they win, they win; o look, look, look, sir, for heaven's sake look, the Britain's fly, the Britain's fly. Victoria. Enter Swetonius, soldiers, and captains.

sp.speaker: Swet.
sp.l: Soft, soft, pursue it soft; excellent soldiers,
Close, my brave fellows, honourable Romans:
O cool thy mettle Junius, they are ours,
The world cannot redeem 'em: stern Petillius,
Govern the conquest nobly: soft, good soldiers.

sp.speaker: Bond.
sp.l: Shame, whither fly ye, ye unlucky Britain's?
Will ye creep into your mother's wombs again? Back cowards,
Hares, fearful hares, doves in your angers; leave me?
Leave your Queen desolate? her hapless children
To Roman rape again and fury?

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: Fly, ye buzzards,
Ye have wings enough, ye fear: get thee gone, woman,
Shame tread upon thy heels: all's lost, all's lost, hark,
Hark how the Romans ring our kneels. Ext. bond. etc.

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.l: Good uncle,
Let me go too.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: No boy, thy fortune's mine,
I must not leave thee; get behind me; shake not,
I'll breech ye, if ye do boy: come, brave Romans,
All is not lost yet.

sp.speaker: Jun.
sp.p: Now I'll thank thee, caratach. Fight. Drums.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: Thou art a soldier: strike home, home; have at ye.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: His blows fall like huge sledges on an anvil.

sp.speaker: Dec.
sp.l: I am weary.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: So am I.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: Send more swords to me.

sp.speaker: Jun.
sp.l: Let's sit and rest. Sit down.

sp.speaker: Dru.
sp.l: What think ye now?

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: O Drusus,
I have lost mine honour, lost my name,
Lost all that was my light: these are true Romans,
And I a Britain coward, a base coward;
Guide me where nothing is but desolation,
That I may never more behold the face
Of man, or mankind know me: oh blind fortune,
Hast thou abused me thus?

sp.speaker: Dru.
sp.l: Good sir, be comforted;
It was your wisdom ruled ye; pray ye go home,
Your day is yet to come, when this great fortune
Shall be but foil unto it. Retreat.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.p: Fool, fool, coward. Exit Penyus and Drusus.

div.stage: Enter Swetonius, Demetrius, soldiers, drum and colours.

sp.speaker: Swet.
sp.l: Draw in, draw in: well have ye fought, and worthy
Rome's noble recompense; look to your wounds,
The ground is cold and hurtful: the proud Queen
Has got a fort, and there she and her daughters
Defy us once again. Tomorrow morning
We'll seek her out, and make her know, our fortunes
Stop at no stubborn walls: come, sons of honour,
True virtues heirs; thus hatched with Britain blood,
Let's us march to rest, and set in gules like suns.
Beat a soft march, and each one ease his neighbours.

div.head: Scaena prima.
div.stage: Enter Petillius, Junius, Decius, Demetrius singing.

sp.speaker: Petill.
sp.l: Smooth was his cheek,

sp.speaker: Dec.
sp.l: And his chin it was sleek,

sp.speaker: Jun.
sp.l: With whoop, he has done wooing.

sp.speaker: Dem.
