sp.l: Junius was this captain's name,
A lad for a lass's viewing,

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: Full black his eye, and plump his thigh.

sp.speaker: Dec.
sp.l: Made up for love's pursuing:

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: Smooth was his cheek,

sp.speaker: Petill.
sp.l: And his chin it was sleek.

sp.speaker: Jun.
sp.l: With whoop, he has done wooing.

sp.speaker: Petill.
sp.l: O my vexed thief, art thou come home again?
Are thy brains perfect?

sp.speaker: Jun.
sp.l: Sound as bells.

sp.speaker: Petill.
sp.l: Thy back-worm
Quiet, and cast his sting, boy?

sp.speaker: Jun.
sp.l: Dead, Petillius,
Dead to all folly, and now my anger only.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: Why, that's well said: hang Cupid and his quiver,
A drunken brawling boy; thy honoured saint
Be thy ten shillings, Junius; there's the money,
And there's the ware; square dealing: this but sweats thee
Like a nesh nag, and makes thee look pin buttocked;
The other runs thee whining up and down
Like a pig in a storm, fills thy brains full of ballads,
And shows thee like a long lent, thy brave body
Turned to a tail of greenfish without butter.

sp.speaker: Dec.
sp.l: When thou lovest next, love a good cup of wine,
A mistress for a King, she leaps to kiss thee,
Her red and white's her own; she makes good blood,
Takes none away; what she heats sleep can help,
Without a groping surgeon.

sp.speaker: Jun.
sp.l: I am counselled,
And henceforth, when I dote again, —

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: Take heed,
Ye had almost paid for't.

sp.speaker: Petil.
sp.l: Love no more great ladies,
Thou canst not step amiss then; there's no delight in 'em;
All's in the whistling of their snatched up silks;
They're only made for handsome view, not handling;
Their bodies of so weak and wash a temper,
A rough-paced bed will shake 'em all to pieces;
A tough hen pulls their teeth out, tires their souls;
Plenae rimarum sunt, they are full of rennet,
And take the skin off where they are tasted; shun 'em,
They live in cullises like rotten cocks
Stewed to a tenderness, that holds no tack:
Give me a thing I may crush.

sp.speaker: Jun.
sp.l: Thou speak'st truly:
The wars shall be my mistress now.

sp.speaker: Petil.
sp.l: Well chosen,
For she's a bownsing lass, she'll kiss thee at night, boy,
And break thy pate i'th' morning.

sp.speaker: Jun.
sp.l: Yesterday
I found those favours infinite.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: Wench good enough,
But that she talks too loud.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: She talks to th' purpose,
Which never woman did yet: she'll hold grappling,
And he that lays on best, is her best servant:
All other loves are mere catching of dotrels,
Stretching of legs out only, and trim laziness.Enter
Here comes the general. Swet. Curius and Macer.

sp.speaker: Swet.
sp.l: I am glad I have found ye:
Are those come in yet that pursued bold Caratach?

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: Not yet sir, for I think they mean to lodge him;
Take him I know they dare not, 'twill be dangerous.

sp.speaker: Swet.
sp.l: Then haste Petillius, haste to Penyus,
I fear the strong conceit of what disgrace
Has pulled upon himself, will be his ruin:
I fear his soldier's fury too; haste presently,
I would not lose him for all Britain. Give him, Petillius,

sp.speaker: Petil.
sp.l: That that shall choke him.

sp.speaker: Swet.
sp.l: All the noble counsel,
His fault forgiven too, his place, his honour,

sp.speaker: Petill.
sp.l: For me, I think, as handsome.

sp.speaker: Swet.
sp.l: All the comfort;
And tell the soldier, 'twas on our command
He drew not to the battle.

sp.speaker: Petil.
sp.l: I conceive sir,
And will do that shall cure all.

sp.speaker: Swet.
sp.l: Bring him with ye
Before the Queen's fort, and his forces with him,
There you shall find us following of our conquest:
Make haste.

sp.speaker: Petil.
sp.l: The best I may. Exit.

sp.speaker: Swet.
sp.l: And noble gentlemen,
Up to your companies: we'll presently
Upon the Queen's pursuit: there's nothing done
Till she be seized; without her nothing won. Exeunt.

div.head: Scaena secunda.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: How does my boy?

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.l: I would do well, my heart's well;
I do not fear.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: My good boy.

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.l: I know, uncle,
We must all die; my little brother died,
I saw him die, and he died smiling: sure,
There's no great pain in't uncle. But pray tell me,
Whither must we go when we are dead?

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: Strange questions!
Why, to the blessedest place boy: ever sweetness
And happiness dwells there.

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.l: Will you come to me?

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: Yes, my sweet boy.

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.l: Mine aunt too, and my cousins?

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: All, my good child.

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.l: No Romans, uncle?

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: No, boy.

sp.speaker: Heng.
sp.l: I should be loath to meet them there.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: No ill men,
That live by violence, and strong oppression,
Come thither: 't is for those the gods love, good men.

sp.speaker: Heng.
sp.l: Why, then I care not when I go; for surely
I am persuaded they love me: I never
Blasphemed 'em, uncle, nor transgressed my parents;
I always said my prayers.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: Thou shalt go, then,
Indeed thou shalt.

sp.speaker: Heng.
sp.l: When they please.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: That's my good boy.
Art thou not weary, Hengo?

sp.speaker: Heng.
sp.l: Weary, uncle?
I have heard you say you have marched all day in armour.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: I have, boy.

sp.speaker: Hengo.
sp.l: Am not I your kinsman?

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: Yes.

sp.speaker: Heng.
sp.l: And am not I as fully allied unto you
In those brave things, as blood?

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: Thou art too tender.

sp.speaker: Heng.
sp.l: To go upon my legs? they were made to bear me:
I can play twenty mile a day; I see no reason
But, to preserve my country and myself,
I should march forty.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: What, wouldst thou be
Living to wear a man's strength?

sp.speaker: Heng.
sp.l: Why a Caratach,
A roman-hater, a scourge sent from heavenDrum.
To whip these proud thieves from our kingdom. Hark,
Hark, uncle, hark, I hear a drum.

div.stage: Enter Judas and his people to the door.

sp.speaker: Jud.
sp.l: Beat softly,
Softly, I say; they are here: who dare charge?

sp.speaker: 1 soldier
sp.l: He
That dares be knocked of th' head: I'll not come near him.

sp.speaker: Jud.
sp.l: Retire again, and watch then. How he stares!
He as eyes would kill a dragon: mark the boy well;
If we could take or kill him. A — on ye,
How fierce ye look? see how he broods the boy;
The devil dwells in's scabbard. Back, I say,
Apace, apace, he as found us. They retire.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: Do ye hunt us?

sp.speaker: Heng.
sp.l: Uncle, good uncle see, the thin starved rascal,
The eating Roman, see where he threads the thickets:
Kill him, dear uncle, kill him; one good blow
To knock his brains into his breech: strikes head off,
That I may piss in is face.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: Do ye make us foxes?
Here, hold my charging-staff, and keep the place, boy.
I am at bay, and like a bull I'll bear me.
Stand, stand, ye rogues, ye squirrels. Exit.

sp.speaker: Heng.
sp.l: Now he pays 'em:
Oh that I had a man's strength.

sp.speaker: Jud.
sp.l: Here's the boy;
Mine own, I thank my fortune.

sp.speaker: Heng.
sp.l: Uncle, uncle;
Famine is fallen upon me, uncle.

sp.speaker: Jud.
sp.l: Come, sir,
Yield willingly, your uncle is out of hearing;
I'll tickle your young tail else.

sp.speaker: Heng.
sp.l: I defy thee,
Thou mock-made man of mat: charge home, sirrah:
Hang thee, base slave, thou shakest.

sp.speaker: Jud.
sp.l: Upon my conscience
The boy will beat me: how it looks, how bravely,
How confident the worm is: a scabbed boy
To handle me thus? yield, or I cut thy head off.

sp.speaker: Heng.
sp.l: Thou dar'st not cut my finger: here 't is, touch it.

sp.speaker: Jud.
sp.l: The boy speaks sword and buckler. Prithee yield, boy:
Come, here is an apple; yield.

sp.speaker: Heng.
sp.l: By — he fears me.
I'll give you sharper language: when, ye coward,
When come ye up?

sp.speaker: Jud.
sp.l: If he should beat me —

sp.speaker: Heng.
sp.l: When, sir?
I long to kill thee; come, thou canst not scape me,
I have twenty ways to charge thee; twenty deaths
Attend my bloody staff.

sp.speaker: Jud.
sp.l: Sure 't is the devil,
A dwarf, devil in a doubler.

sp.speaker: Heng.
sp.p: I have killed a captain, sirrah, a brave captain, and when I have done. I have kicked him thus. Look here, see how I charge this staff.

sp.speaker: Jud.
sp.l: Most certain
This boy will cut my throat, yet.

sp.speaker: 1 soldier
sp.l: Flee, flee, he kills us.

sp.speaker: 2 soldier
sp.l: He comes, he comes.

sp.speaker: Jud.
sp.l: The devil take the hindmost.

sp.speaker: Heng.
sp.l: Run, run, ye rogues, ye precious rogues, ye rank rogues.
'A comes, 'a comes, 'a comes, 'a comes: that is he, boys.
What a brave cry they make?

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: How does my chicken?

sp.speaker: Heng.
sp.l: I'faith, uncle, grown a soldier, a great soldier;
For by the virtue of your charging-staff,
And a strange fighting face I put upon 't,
I have outbraved hunger.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: That's my boy, my sweet boy.
Here, here's a Roman is head for thee.

sp.speaker: Heng.
sp.l: Good provision.
Before I starve, my sweet-faced gentleman,
I'll try your favour.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: A right complete soldier.
Come, chicken, let's go seek some place of strength
(The country is full of scouts) to rest a while in,
Thou wilt not else be able to endure.
The journey to my country, fruits, and water,
Must be your food a while, boy.

sp.speaker: Heng.
sp.l: Any thing:
I can eat moss, nay, I can live on anger,
To vex these Romans. Let is be wary, uncle.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: I warrant thee; come cheerfully.

sp.speaker: Heng.
sp.l: And boldly. Exeunt.

div.head: Scaena tertia.

sp.speaker: Reg.
sp.l: The soldier shall not grieve ye.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: Pray ye forsake me;
Look not upon me, as ye love your honours;
I am so cold a coward, my infection
Will choke your virtues like a damp else.

sp.speaker: Dru.
sp.l: Dear captain.

sp.speaker: Reg.
sp.l: Most honoured sir.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: Most hated, most abhorred;
Say so, and than ye know me, nay, ye please me.
O my dear credit, my dear credit.

sp.speaker: Reg.
sp.l: Sure
His mind is dangerous.

sp.speaker: Dru.
sp.l: The good gods cure it.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: My honour got thorough fire, thorough stubborn, breaches
Thorough battles that have been as hard to win as heaven,
Thorough death himself, in all his horrid trims,
Is gone for ever, ever, ever, gentlemen,
And now I am left to scornful tales and laughters,
To hootings at, pointing with fingers, that's he,
That's the brave gentleman forsook the battle,
The most wise Penyus, the disputing coward.
O my good sword, break from my side, and kill me;
Cut out the coward from my heart.

sp.speaker: Reg.
sp.l: Ye are none.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: He lies that says so: by — he lies, lies basely,
Baser than I have done. Come, soldiers, seek me,
I have robbed ye of your virtues: justice, seek me,
I have broke my fair obedience, lost: shame take me,
Take me, and swallow me, make ballads of me;
Shame, endless shame: and pray do you forsake me.

sp.speaker: Dru.
sp.l: What shall we do?

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: Good gentlemen forsake me:
You were not wont to be commanded. Friends, pray do it,
And do not fear; for as I am a coward
I will not hurt myself: when that mind takes me,
I'll call to you, and ask your help. I dare not.

sp.speaker: Petill.
sp.l: Good morrow, gentlemen; where's the tribune?

sp.speaker: Reg.
sp.l: There.

sp.speaker: Dru.
sp.l: Whence come ye, good Petillius?

sp.speaker: Petill.
sp.l: From the general.

sp.speaker: Dru.
sp.l: With what, for heaven's sake?

sp.speaker: Petill.
sp.l: With good counsel, Drusus,
And love, to comfort him.

sp.speaker: Dru.
sp.l: Good Regulus
Step to the soldier, and allay his anger;
For he is wild as winter.

sp.speaker: Petill.
sp.l: O, are ye there? have at ye. Sure he is dead,
It cannot be he dare out live this fortune:
He must die, 't is most necessary; men expect it;
And thought of life in him, goes beyond coward.
Forsake the field so basely? fie upon 't:
So poorly to betray his worth? so coldly
To cut all credit from the soldier? sure
If this man mean to live, as I should think it
Beyond belief, he must retire where never
The name of Rome, the voice of arms, or honour
Was known or heard of yet: he is certain dead,
Or strongly means it; he is no soldier else,
No Roman in him; all he has done, but outside,
Fought either drunk or desperate. Now he rises.
How does lord Penyus?

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: As ye see.

sp.speaker: Petill.
sp.l: I am glad on 't;
Continue so still. The lord general,
The valiant general, great Swetonius —

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: No more of me is spoken; my name's perished.

sp.speaker: Petill.
sp.l: He that commanded fortune and the day
By his own valour and discretion,
When, as some say, Penyus refused to come,
But I believe 'em not, sent me to see ye.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: Ye are welcome; and pray see me; see me well,
Ye shall not see me long.

sp.speaker: Petill.
sp.l: I hope so, Penyus;
The gods defend, sir.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: See me, and understand me: this is he
Left to fill up your triumph; he that basely
Whistled his honour off to th' wind; that coldly
Shrunk in his politic head, when Rome like reapers
Sweat blood, and spirit, for a glorious harvest,
And bound it up, and brought it off: that fool,
That having gold and copper offered him,
Refused the wealth, and took the waste: that soldier
That being courted by loud fame and fortune,
Labour in one hand, that propounds us gods,
And in the other, glory that creates us,
Yet durst doubt, and be damned.

sp.speaker: Petill.
sp.l: It was an error.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: A foul one, and a black one.

sp.speaker: Petill.
sp.l: Yet the blackest
May be washed white again.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: Never.

sp.speaker: Petill.
sp.l: Your leave, sir,
And I beseech ye note me; for I love ye,
And bring along all comfort: are we gods,
Allied to no infirmities? are our natures
More than men's natures? when we slip a little
Out of the way of virtue, are we lost?
Is there no medicine called sweet mercy?

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: None, Petillius;
There is no mercy in mankind can reach me,
Nor is it fit it should; I have sinned beyond it.

sp.speaker: Petill.
sp.l: Forgiveness meets with all faults.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: 'T is all faults,
All sins I can commit, to be forgiven:
'T is loss of whole man in me, my discretion
To be so stupid, to arrive at pardon.

sp.speaker: Petill.
sp.l: O but the general —

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: He's a brave gentleman,
A valiant, and a loving; and I dare say
He would, as far as honour durst direct him,
Make even with my fault: but 't is not honest,
Nor in his power: examples that may nourish
Neglect and disobedience in whole bodies,
And totter the estates and faiths of armies,
Must not be played withal; nor out of pity
Make a general forget his duty:
Nor dare I hope more from him then is worthy.

sp.speaker: Petill.
sp.l: What would ye do?

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: Die.

sp.speaker: Petill.
sp.l: So would sullen children,
Women that want their wills, slaves, disobedient,
That fear the law, die. Fie, great captain; you
A man to rule men, to have thousand lives
Under your regiment, and let your passion
Betray your reason? I bring you all forgiveness,
The noblest kind commends, your place, your honour.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: Prithee no more; 't is foolish: didst not thou?
By — thou didst, I overheard thee, there,
There where thou standst now, deliver me for rascal,
Poor, dead, cold coward, miserable, wretched,
If I outlived this ruin?

sp.speaker: Petill.
sp.l: I?

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: And thou didst it nobly,
Like a true man, a soldier: and I thank thee,
I thank thee, good Petillius; thus I thank thee.

sp.speaker: Petill.
sp.l: Since ye are so justly made up, let me tell ye
'Tis fit ye die indeed.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: O how thou lovest me!

sp.speaker: Petill.
sp.l: For say he had forgiven ye; say the people's whispers
Were tame again, the time run out for wonder,
What must your own command think, from whose swords
Ye have taken off the edges, from whose valours
The due and recompense of arms; nay, made it doubtful
Whether they knew obedience? must not these kill ye?
Say they are won to pardon ye, by mere miracle
Brought to forgive ye; what old valiant soldier,
What man that loves to fight, and fight for Rome,
Will ever follow you more? dare ye know these ventures?
If so, I bring ye comfort; dare ye take it?

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: No, no, Petillius, no.

sp.speaker: Petill.
sp.l: If your mind serve ye,
Ye may live still; but how? yet pardon me,
You may outwear all too; but when? and certain
There is a mercy for each fault, if tamely
A man will take 't upon conditions.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: No, by no means: I am only thinking now, sir,
(For I am resolved to go) of a most base death,
Fitting the baseness of my fault. I'll hang,

sp.speaker: Petill.
sp.l: Ye shall not; you're a gentleman I honour,
I would else flatter ye, and force ye live,
Which is far baser. Hanging? 't is a dog's death,
An end for slaves.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: The fitter for my baseness.

sp.speaker: Petill.
sp.p: Besides, the man that is hanged, preaches his end, and sits a sign for all the world to gape at.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: That's true: I'll take a fitter poison.

sp.speaker: Petill.
sp.l: No,
'T is equal ill; the death of rats, and women,
Lovers, and lazy boys, that fear correction.
Die like a man.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: Why my sword then.

sp.speaker: Petill.
sp.l: Ay, if your sword be sharp, sir,
There is nothing under heaven that is like your sword;
Your sword is a death indeed.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: It shall be sharp, sir.

sp.speaker: Petill.
sp.l: Why Mithridates was an arrant ass
To die by poison, if all Bosphorus
Could lend him swords: your sword must do the deed:
'T is shame to die choked, fame to die and bleed.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: Thou hast: confirmed me: and, my good Petillius,
Tell me no more I may live.

sp.speaker: Petill.
sp.l: 'T was my commission;
But now I see ye in a nobler way,
A way to make all even.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: Farewell, captain:
Be a good man, and fight well: be obedient:
Command thyself, and then thy men. Why shakest thou?

sp.speaker: Petill.
sp.l: I do not, sir.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: I would thou hadst, Petillius:
I would find something to forsake the world with
Worthy the man that dies: a kind of earthquake
Thorough all stern valours but mine own.

sp.speaker: Petill.
sp.l: I feel now
A kind of trembling in me.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: Keep it still,
As thou lovest virtue, keep it.

sp.speaker: Petill.
sp.l: And brave captain,
The great and honoured Penyus.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: That again:
Oh how it heightens me! again, Petillius.

sp.speaker: Petill.
sp.l: Most excellent commander.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: Those were mine,
Mine, only mine.

sp.speaker: Petill.
sp.l: They are still.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: Then to keep 'em
For ever falling more, have at ye, heavens,
Ye everlasting powers, I am yours: the work's done,
That neither fire, nor age, nor melting envy
Shall ever conquer. Carry my last words
To the great general: kiss his hands, and say,
My soul I give to heaven, my fault to justice
Which I have done upon myself: my virtue,
If ever there was any in poor Penyus,
Made more, and happier, light on him. I faint.
And where there is a foe, I wish him fortune.
I die: lie lightly on my ashes, gentle earth.

sp.speaker: Petill.
sp.l: And on my sin. Farewell, great Penyus,
The soldier is in fury. Now I am glad
'T is done before he comes. This way, for me,
The way of toil; for thee, the way of honour. Exit.

div.stage: Enter Drusus and Regulus, with soldiers.

sp.speaker: Soldier
sp.l: Kill him, kill him, kill him.

sp.speaker: Dru.
sp.l: What will ye do?

sp.speaker: Reg.
sp.l: Good soldiers, honest soldiers.

sp.speaker: Soldier
sp.l: Kill him, kill him, kill him.

sp.speaker: Dru.
sp.l: Kill us first; we command too.

sp.speaker: Reg.
sp.l: Valiant soldiers,
Consider but whose life ye seek. O Drusus,
Bid him be gone, he dies else. Shall Rome say
(Ye most approved soldiers) her dear children
Devoured the fathers of the fights? shall rage
And stubborn fury guide those swords to slaughter,
To slaughter of their own, to civil ruin?

sp.speaker: Dru.
sp.l: O let 'em in: all is done, all is ended, Regulus,
Penyus has found his last eclipse. Come, soldiers,
Come, and behold your miseries: come bravely,
Full of your mutinous and bloody angers,
And here bestow your darts. O only Roman,
Oh father of the wars.

sp.speaker: Reg.
sp.l: Why stand ye stupid?
Where be your killing furies? whose sword now
Shall first be sheathed in Penyus? do ye weep?
Howl out, ye wretches, ye have cause: howl ever.
Who shall now lead ye fortunate? whose valour
Preserve ye to the glory of your country?
Who shall march out before ye, coyed and courted
By all the mistresses of war, care, counsel,
Quick-eyed experience, and victory twined to him?
Who shall beget ye deeds beyond inheritance
To speak your names, and keep your honours living,
When children fail, and time that takes all with him,
Build houses for ye to oblivion?

sp.speaker: Dru.
sp.l: O ye poor desperate fools: no more now, soldiers;
Go home, and hang your arms up; let just rot 'em;
And humble your stern valours to soft prayers;
For ye have sunk the frame of all your virtues;
The sun that warmed your bloods is set for ever:
I'll kiss thy honoured cheek. Fare well, great Penyus,
Thou thunderbolt, farewell. Take up the body:
Tomorrow morning to the camp convey it.
There to receive due ceremonies. That eye
That blinds himself with weeping, gets most glory.

div.head: Scaena quarta.
div.stage: Enter Swetonius, Junius, Decius, Demetrius, Curius, and soldiers: Bonduca, two daughters, and Nennius, above. Drum and colours.

sp.speaker: Swet.
sp.l: Bring up the catapults and shake the wall,
We will not be outbraved thus.

sp.speaker: Nen.
sp.l: Shake the earth,
Ye cannot shake our souls. Bring up your rams,
And with their armed heads, make the fort totter,
Ye do but rock us into death. Exit Nennius.

sp.speaker: Jun.
sp.l: See sir,
See the Icenian Queen in all her glory
From the strong battlements proudly appearing,
As if she meant to give us lashes.

sp.speaker: Dec.
sp.l: Yield, Queen.

sp.speaker: Bond.
sp.l: I am unacquainted with that language, roman.

sp.speaker: Swet.
sp.l: Yield, honoured lady, and expect our mercy,
We love thy nobleness.

sp.speaker: Bond.
sp.l: I thank ye, ye say well;
But mercy and love are sins in Rome and hell.

sp.speaker: Swet.
sp.l: Ye cannot scape our strength; ye must yield, lady,
Ye must adore and fear the power of Rome.

sp.speaker: Bond.
sp.l: If Rome be earthly, why should any knee
With bending adoration worship her?
She's vicious; and your partial selves confess,
Aspires the height of all impiety:
Therefore 'tis fitter I should reverence
The thatched houses where the Britain's dwell
In careless mirth, where the blessed household gods
See naught but chaste and simple purity.
'Tis not high power that makes a place divine,
Nor that the men from gods derive their line.
But sacred thoughts in holy bosoms stored,
Make people noble, and the place adored.

sp.speaker: Swet.
sp.l: Beat the wall deeper.

sp.speaker: Bond.
sp.l: Beat it to the centre,
We will not sink one thought.

sp.speaker: Swet.
sp.l: I'll make ye.

sp.speaker: Bond.
sp.l: No.

sp.speaker: 2. Dan.
sp.l: O mother, these are fearful hours: speak gently
To these fierce men, they will afford ye pity.

sp.speaker: Bond.
sp.l: Pity? thou fearful girl; 'tis for those wretches
That misery makes tame. Wouldst thou live less?
Wast not thou born a Princess? Can my blood,
And thy brave father's spirit, suffer in thee
So base a separation from thyself,
As mercy from these tyrants? Thou lovest lust sure,
And longest to prostitute thy youth and beauty
To common slaves for bread. Say they had mercy;
The devil a relenting conscience:
The lives of King's rest in their diadems,
Which to their bodies lively souls do give,
And ceasing to be Kings, they cease to live.
Show such another fear, and —
I'll fling thee to their fury.

sp.speaker: Swet.
sp.l: He is dead then?

sp.speaker: Petill.
sp.l: I think so certainly; yet all my means, sir,
Even to the hazard of my life —

sp.speaker: Swet.
sp.l: No more:
We must not seem to mourn here.

sp.speaker: Dec.
sp.l: There's a breach made,
Is it your will we charge, sir?

sp.speaker: Swet.
sp.l: Once more mercy,
Mercy to all that yield.

sp.speaker: Bond.
sp.l: I scorn to answer:
Speak to him girl; and hear thy sister.

sp.speaker: 1. Daugh.
sp.l: General,
Hear me, and mark me well, and look upon me
Directly in my face, my woman's face,
Whose only beauty is the hate it bears ye;
See with thy narrowest eyes, thy sharpest wishes,
Into my soul, and see what there inhabits;
See if one fear, one shadow of a terror,
One paleness dare appear but from my anger,
To lay hold on your mercies. No, ye fools,
Poor fortune's fools, we were not born for triumphs,
To follow your gay sports, and fill your slaves
With hoots and acclamations.

sp.speaker: Petill.
sp.l: Brave behaviour.

sp.speaker: 1 daughter
sp.l: The children of as great as Rome, as noble,
Our names before her, and our deeds her envy;
Must we gild o'er your conquest , make your state,
That is not fairly strong, but fortunate?
No, no, ye Romans, we have ways to scape ye,
To make ye poor again, indeed our prisoners,
And stick our triumphs full.

sp.speaker: Petill.
sp.l: Is death, I shall love her.

sp.speaker: 1 daughter
sp.l: To torture ye with suffering, like our slaves;
To make ye curse our patience, wish the world
Were lost again, to win us only, and esteem
The end of all ambitions.

sp.speaker: Bond.
sp.l: Do ye wonder?
We'll make our monuments in spite of fortune,
In spite of all your eagles wings: we'll work
A pitch above ye; and from our height we'll stoop
As fearless of your bloody fears; and fortunate,
As if we preyed on heartless doves.

sp.speaker: Swet.
sp.l: Strange stiffness.
Decius, go charge the breach. Exit Decius.

sp.speaker: Bond.
sp.l: Charge it home, Roman,
We shall deceive thee else. Where is Nennius?

sp.speaker: Nen.
sp.l: They have made a mighty breach.

sp.speaker: Bond.
sp.l: Stick in thy body,
And make it good but half an hour.

sp.speaker: Nen.
sp.l: I'll do it.

sp.speaker: 1 daughter
sp.l: And then be sure to die.

sp.speaker: Nen.
sp.l: It shall go hard else.

sp.speaker: Bond.
sp.l: Fare well with all my heart; we shall meet yonder,
Where few of these must come.

sp.speaker: Nen.
sp.l: Gods take thee, lady.

sp.speaker: Bond.
sp.l: Bring up the swords, and poison.

div.stage: Enter one with swords, and a great cup.

sp.speaker: 2 daugh.
sp.l: O my fortune!

sp.speaker: Bond.
sp.l: How, how, ye whore?

sp.speaker: 2 daugh.
sp.l: Good mother, nothing to offend ye.

sp.speaker: Bond.
sp.l: Here, wench:
Behold us, Romans.

sp.speaker: Swet.
sp.l: Mercy yet.

sp.speaker: Bond.
sp.l: No talking:
Puff; there goes all your pity. Come, short prayers,
And let is dispatch the business: you begin,
Shrink not; I'll see ye do 't.

sp.speaker: 2 daugh.
sp.l: O gentle mother,
Oh Romans, oh my heart; I dare not.

sp.speaker: Swet.
sp.l: Woman, woman,
Unnatural woman.

sp.speaker: 2 daugh.
sp.l: O persuade her, Romans:
Alas, I am young, and would live. Noble mother,
Can ye kill that ye gave life? are my years
Fit for destruction?

sp.speaker: Swet.
sp.l: Yield, and be a Queen still,
A mother, and a friend.

sp.speaker: Bond.
sp.l: Ye talk: come, hold it,
And put it home.

sp.speaker: 1 daughter
sp.l: Fie, sister, fie,
What would you live to be?

sp.speaker: Bond.
sp.l: A whore still.

sp.speaker: 2 daugh.
sp.l: Mercy.

sp.speaker: Swet.
sp.l: Hear her, thou wretched woman.

sp.speaker: 2 daugh.
sp.l: Mercy, mother:
Oh whither will you send me? I was once
Your darling, your delight.

sp.speaker: Bond.
sp.l: O gods,
Fear in my family? do it, and nobly.

sp.speaker: 2 daugh.
sp.l: O do not frown then.

sp.speaker: 1 daughter
sp.l: Do it, worthy sister:
'T is nothing, 't is a pleasure; we'll go with ye.

sp.speaker: 2 daugh.
sp.l: O if I knew but whither.

sp.speaker: 1 daughter
sp.l: To the blessed,
Where we shall meet our father.

sp.speaker: Swet.
sp.l: Woman.

sp.speaker: Bond.
sp.l: Talk not.

sp.speaker: 1 daughter
sp.l: Where nothing but true joy is.

sp.speaker: Bond.
sp.p: That is a good wench, mine own sweet girl; put it close to thee.

sp.speaker: 2 daugh.
sp.l: O comfort me still, for heaven's sake.

sp.speaker: 1 daughter
sp.l: Where eternal
Our youths are, and our beauties; where no wars come,
Nor lustful slaves to ravish us.

sp.speaker: 2 daugh.
sp.l: That steels me:
A long farewell to this world.

sp.speaker: Bond.
sp.l: Good: I'll help thee.

sp.speaker: 1 daughter
sp.l: The next is mine.
Show me a Roman lady in all your storeys,
Dare do this for her honour: they are cowards,
Eat coals like compelled cats: your great saint Lucrece
Died not for honour; Tarquin topped her well,
And mad she could not hold him, bled.

sp.speaker: Petill.
sp.l: By —
I am in love: I would give an hundred pound now
But to lie with this woman's behaviour. O the devil.

sp.speaker: 1 daughter
sp.l: Ye shall see me example. All your Rome,
If I were proud, and loved ambition;
If I were lustful, all your ways of pleasure;
If I were greedy, all the wealth ye conquer —

sp.speaker: Bond.
sp.l: Make haste.

sp.speaker: 1 daughter
sp.l: I will. Could not entice to live
But two short hours this frailty: would ye learn
How to die bravely, Romans, to fling off
This case of flesh, lose all your cares for ever?
Live as we have done, well, and fear the gods,
Hunt honour, and not nations with your swords,
Keep your minds humble, your devotions high;
So shall ye learn the noblest part, to die.

sp.speaker: Bond.
sp.l: I come, wench; to ye all fates hangmen; you
That case the aged destinies, and cut
The threads of kingdoms, as they draw 'em: here,
Here is a draught would ask no less than Caesar
To pledge it for the glory's sake.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.l: Great lady.

sp.speaker: Swet.
sp.l: Make up your own conditions.

sp.speaker: Bond.
sp.l: So we will.

sp.speaker: Swet.
sp.l: Stay.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: Stay.

sp.speaker: Swet.
sp.l: Be any thing.

sp.speaker: Bond.
sp.l: A saint, Swetonius,
When thou shalt fear, and die like a slave. Ye fool,
Ye should have tied up, death first, when ye conquered,
Ye sweat for us in vain else: see him here,
He is ours still, and our friend; laughs at your pities;
And we command him with as easy reins
As do our enemies. I feel the poison.
Poor vanquished Romans, with what matchless tortures
Could I now rack ye? But I pity ye,
Desiring to die quiet: nay, so much
I hate to prosecute my victory,
That I will give ye counsel ere I die.
If you will keep your laws and empire whole,
Place in your Roman flesh a Britain soul.

sp.speaker: Swet.
sp.l: Desperate and strange.

sp.speaker: Dec.
sp.l: 'T is won, sir, and the Britain's
All put to th' sword.

sp.speaker: Swet.
sp.l: Give her fair funeral;
She was truly noble, and a Queen.

sp.speaker: Petill.
sp.l: — take it,
A love-mange grown upon me? what, a spirit?

sp.speaker: Jun.
sp.l: I am glad of this, I have found ye.

sp.speaker: Petill.
sp.l: In my belly,
Oh how it tumbles?

sp.speaker: Jun.
sp.l: Ye good gods, I thank ye. Exeunt.

div.head: Scaena prima.
div.stage: Enter Caratach upon a rock, and Hengo by him, sleeping.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: Thus we afflicted Britain's climb for safeties,
And to avoid our dangers, seek destructions;
Thus we awake to sorrows. O thou woman,
Thou agent for adversities, what curses
This day belong to thy improvidence?
To Brittany by thy means, what sad millions
Of widows weeping eyes? The strong man's valour
Thou hast betrayed to fury; the child's fortune
To fear, and want of friends: whose pieties
Might wipe his mournings off, and build his sorrows
A house of rest by his blessed ancestor:
The virgins thou hast robbed of all their wishes,
Blasted their blowing hopes, turned their songs,
Their mirthful marriage songs to funerals,
The land thou hast left a wilderness of wretches.
The boy begins to stir: thy safety made,
Would my soul were in heaven.

sp.speaker: Heng.
sp.l: O noble uncle,
Look out; I dreamed we were betrayed.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: No harm, boy;
'T is but thy emptiness that breeds these fancies;
Thou shalt have meat anon.

sp.speaker: Heng.
sp.l: A little, uncle,
And I shall hold out bravely. What are those?
Look, uncle, look, those multitudes that march there?
They come upon us stealing by.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: I see 'em;
And prithee be not fearful.

sp.speaker: Heng.
sp.l: Now ye hate me,
Would I were dead.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: Thou knowest I love thee dear.

sp.speaker: Heng.
sp.l: Did I ere shrink yet, uncle? were I a man now,
I should be angry with ye.

div.stage: Enter Drusus, Regulus, and soldiers, with Penyus' hearse, drums and colours.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: My sweet chicken,
See, they have reached us, and as it seems they bear
Some soldier's body, by their solemn gestures,
And sad solemnities; it well appears too
To be of eminence. Most worthy soldiers,
Let me entreat your knowledge to inform me
What noble body that is which you bear
With such a sad and ceremonious grief,
As if ye meant to woo the world and nature
To be in love with death? Most honourable
Excellent Romans, by your ancient valours,
As ye love fame, resolve me.

sp.speaker: Soldier
sp.l: 'T is the body
Of the great captain Penyus, by himself
Made cold and spiritless.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: O stay, ye Romans,
By the religion which you owe those gods
That lead ye on to victories, by those glories
Which made even pride a virtue in ye.

sp.speaker: Dru.
sp.l: Stay:
What is thy will, caratach?

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: Set down the body,
The body of the noblest of all Romans,
As ye expect an offering at your graves
From your friends sorrows, set it down a while,
That with your griefs an enemy may mingle;
A noble enemy that loves a soldier;
And lend a tear to virtue: even your foes,
Your wild foes, as you called us, are yet stored
With fair affections, our hearts fresh, our spirits,
Though sometimes stubborn, yet when virtue dies,
Soft and relenting as a virgin's prayers.
O set it down.

sp.speaker: Dru.
sp.l: Set down the body, soldiers.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: Thou hallowed relic, thou rich diamond
Cut with thine own dust; thou for whose wide fame
The world appears too narrow, man's all thoughts,
Had they all tongues, too silent; thus I bow
To thy most honoured ashes; though an enemy,
Yet friend to all thy worths: sleep peaceably;
Happiness crown thy soul, and in thy earth
Some laurel fix his seat, there grow, and flourish,
And make thy grave an everlasting triumph.
Fare well all glorious wars, now thou art gone,
And honest arms adieu: all noble battles
Maintained in thirst of honour, not of blood,
Fare well for ever.

sp.speaker: Heng.
sp.l: Was this Roman, uncle,
So good a man?

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: Thou never knew'st thy father.

sp.speaker: Heng.
sp.l: He died before I was born.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: This worthy Roman
Was such another piece of endless honour,
Such a brave soul dwelled in him: their proportions
And faces were not much unlike, boy: excellent natures,
See how it works into his eyes, mine own boy.

sp.speaker: Heng.
sp.l: The multitudes of these men, and their fortunes,
Could never make me fear yet: one man's goodness —

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: O now thou pleasest me: weep still, my child,
As if thou sawest me dead; with such a flux
Or flood of sorrow: still thou pleasest me.
And worthy soldiers, pray receive these pledges,
These hatchments of our griefs, and grace us so much
To place 'em on his hearse. Now if ye please,
Bear off the noble burden; raise his pile
High as Olympus, making heaven to wonder
To see a star upon earth outshining theirs.
And ever loved, ever living be
Thy honoured and most sacred memory.

sp.speaker: Dru.
sp.l: Thou hast done honestly, good Caratach,
And when thou diest, a thousand virtuous Romans
Shall sing thy soul to heaven. Now march on, soldiers.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: Now dry thine eyes, my boy.

sp.speaker: Heng.
sp.l: Are they all gone?
I could have wept this hour yet.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: Come, take cheer,
And raise thy spirit, child: if but this day
Thou canst bear out thy faintness, the night coming
I'll fashion our escape.

sp.speaker: Heng.
sp.l: Pray fear not me;
Indeed I am very hearty.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: Be so still;
His mischiefs lessen, that controls his ill.

sp.speaker: Petill.
sp.l: What do I ail, i' th' name of heaven? I did but see her,
And see her die: she stinks by this time strongly,
Abominably stinks: she was a woman,
A thing I never cared for: but to die so,
So confidently, bravely, strongly; oh the devil,
I have the bots, by —; she scorned us, strangely,
All we could do, or durst do; threatened us
With such a noble anger, and so governed
With such a fiery spirit —; the plain bots;
A — upon the bots, the love-bots: hang me,
Hang me even out of th' way, directly hang me.
O penny pipers, and most painful penners
Of bountiful new ballads, what a subject,
What a sweet subject for your silver sounds,
Is crept upon ye?

sp.speaker: Jun.
sp.l: Here he is; have at him. Sings.
She set the sword unto her breast,
Great pity it was to see,
That three drops of her life-warm blood,
Run trickling down her knee.
Art thou there, bonny boy? and i'faith how dost thou?

sp.speaker: Petill.
sp.l: Well, gramercy, how dost thou? he as found me,
Scented me out: the shame the devil owed me,
He as kept his day with. And what news, Junius?

sp.speaker: Jun.
sp.l: It was an old tale ten thousand times told,
Of a young lady was turned into mould,
Her life was lovely, her death it was bold.

sp.speaker: Petill.
sp.l: A cruel rogue; now he as drawn pursue on me,
He hunts me like a devil. No more singing;
Thou hast got a cold: come, let's go drink some sack, boy.

sp.speaker: Jun.
sp.l: Ha, ha, ha, ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Petill.
sp.l: Why dost thou laugh?
What mares nest hast thou found?

sp.speaker: Jun.
sp.l: Ha, ha, ha.
I cannot laugh alone: Decius, Demetrius,
Curius: oh my sides. Ha, ha, ha, ha,
The strangest jest.

sp.speaker: Petill.
sp.l: Prithee no more.

sp.speaker: Jun.
sp.l: The admirablest fooling.

sp.speaker: Petill.
sp.l: Thou art the prettiest fellow.

sp.speaker: Jun.
sp.l: Sirs.

sp.speaker: Petill.
sp.l: Why Junius,
Prithee away, sweet Junius.

sp.speaker: Jun.
sp.l: Let me sing then.

sp.speaker: Petill.
sp.p: Whoa, here's a stir now: sing a song of six pence, by — (If) prithee; — on 't: Junius.

sp.speaker: Jun.
sp.l: I must either sing, or laugh.

sp.speaker: Petill.
sp.l: And what is your reason?

sp.speaker: Jun.
sp.l: What is that to you?

sp.speaker: Petill.
sp.l: And I must whistle.

sp.speaker: Jun.
sp.l: Do so.
O, I hear 'em coming.

sp.speaker: Petill.
sp.l: I have a little business.

sp.speaker: Jun.
sp.p: Thou shalt not go, believe it: what a gentleman of thy sweet conversation?

sp.speaker: Petill.
sp.l: Captain Junius,
Sweet captain, let me go with all celerity;
Things are not always one: and do not question,
Nor jeer, nor gibe: none of your doleful ditties,
Nor your sweet conversation: you will find than
I may be angered.

sp.speaker: Jun.
sp.l: By no means, Petillius;
Anger a man that never knew passion?
'Tis most impossible: a noble captain,
A wise and generous gentleman?

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: Tom puppy,
Leave this way to abuse me: I have found ye,
But for your mother's sake I will forgive ye.
Your subtle understanding may discover
(As you think) some trim toy to make you merry;
Some straw to tickle ye; but do not trust to 't;
You're a young man, and may do well; be sober;
Carry yourself discreetly.

sp.speaker: Jun.
sp.l: Yes forsooth.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: How does the brave Petillius?

sp.speaker: Jun.
sp.l: Monstrous merry:
We two were talking what a kind of thing
I was when I was in love; what a strange monster
For little boys and girls to wonder at;
How like a fool I looked.

sp.speaker: Dec.
sp.l: So they do all,
Like great dull slavering fools.

sp.speaker: Jun.
sp.l: Petillius saw too.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: No more of this; 'tis scurvy: peace.

sp.speaker: Jun.
sp.l: How nastily,
Indeed how beastly all I did became me?
How I forgotten to blow my nose? there he stands,
An honest and a wise man; if himself
(I dare avouch it boldly, for I know it)
Should find himself in love —

sp.speaker: Petill.
sp.l: I am angry.

sp.speaker: Jun.
sp.l: Surely his wise self would hang his beastly self,
His understanding self so mawl his asse-self —

sp.speaker: Dec.
sp.l: He's bound to do it; for he knows the follies,
The poverties, and baseness that belongs to 't,
He as read upon the reformations long.

sp.speaker: Petill.
sp.l: He has so.

sp.speaker: Jun.
sp.l: 'T is true, and he must do 't:
Nor is it fit indeed any such coward —

sp.speaker: Petill.
sp.l: You'll leave prating.

sp.speaker: Jun.
sp.l: Should dare come near the regiments, specially
Those curious puppies (For believe there are such)
That only love behaviours: those are dog-whelps,
Dwindle away, because a woman dies well;
Commit with passions only: fornicate
With the free spirit merely: you, Petillius,
For you have long observed the world.

sp.speaker: Petill.
sp.l: Dost thou hear?
I'll beat thee damnably within these three hours:
Go pray; may be I'll kill thee. Farewell, Jack daws. Exit.

sp.speaker: Dec.
sp.l: What a strange thing he's grown?

sp.speaker: Jun.
sp.l: I am glad he is so:
And stranger he shall be, before I leave him.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.l: Is 't possible her mere death — ▪

sp.speaker: Jun.
sp.l: I observed him,
And found him taken, infinitely taken
With her bravery: I have followed him,
And seen him kiss his sword since, court his scabbard,
Call dying, dainty dear; her brave mind, mistress;
Casting a thousand ways, to give those forms,
That he might lie with 'em, and get old armours:
He had got me of th' hip once: it shall go hard, friends,
But he shall find his own coin.

sp.speaker: Dec.
sp.l: How now Macer?
Is Judas yet come in? Enter Judas.

sp.speaker: Mac.
sp.l: Yes, and has lost
Most of his men too. Here he is.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.l: What news?

sp.speaker: Jud.
sp.l: I have lodged him; rouse him he that dares.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: Where, Judas?

sp.speaker: Jud.
sp.l: On a steep rock, i' th' woods, the boy too with him,
And there he swears he will keep his Christmas, gentlemen,
But he will come away with full conditions,
Bravely, and like a Britain: he paid part of us,
Yet I think we fought bravely: for mine own part,
I was four several times at half sword with him,
Twice stood his partisan: but the plain truth is,
He's a mere devil, and no man: i' th' end he swinged us,
And swinged us soundly too: he fights by witchcraft:
Yet for all that I see him lodged,

sp.speaker: Jun.
sp.l: Take more men,
And scout him round. Macer, march you along.
What victuals has he?

sp.speaker: Jud.
sp.l: Not a piece of biscuit,
Not so much as will stop a tooth; nor water,
More than they make themselves: they lie
Just like a brace of bear-whelps, close, and crafty,
Sucking their fingers for their food.

sp.speaker: Dec.
sp.l: Cut off then
All hope of that way: take sufficient forces.

sp.speaker: Jun.
sp.l: But use no foul play, on your lives: that man
That does him mischief by deceit, I'll kill him.

sp.speaker: Macer.
sp.l: He shall have fair play, he deserves it.

sp.speaker: Jud.
sp.l: Hark ye,
What should I do there then? you are brave captains,
Most valiant men; go up yourselves; use virtue,
See what will come on 't: pray the gentleman
To come down, and be taken. Ye all know him,
I think ye have felt him too: there ye shall find him,
His sword by his side, plums of a pound weight by him
Will make your chops ache: you'll find it a more labour
To win him living, then climbing of a crow's nest.

sp.speaker: Dec.
sp.l: Away, and compass him; we shall come up
I am sure within these two hours. Watch him close.

sp.speaker: Macer.
sp.l: He shall flee thorough the air, if he escape us.

sp.speaker: Jun.
sp.l: What's this loud lamentation?

sp.speaker: Mac.
sp.l: The dead body
Of the great Penyus is new come to th' camp sir.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: Dead!

sp.speaker: Macer
sp.l: By himself, they say.

sp.speaker: Jun.
sp.l: I feared that fortune.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.l: Peace guide him up to heaven.

sp.speaker: Jun.
sp.p: Away good Macer. Exeunt Macer and Judas.

sp.speaker: Swet.
sp.l: If thou beest guilty,
Some sullen plague thou hatest most light upon thee:
The regiment return on Junius,
He well deserves it.

sp.speaker: Petill.
sp.l: So.

sp.speaker: Swet.
sp.l: Draw out three companies,
Yours Decius, Junius, and thou Petillius,
And make up instantly to Caratach,
He's in the wood before ye; we shall follow
After due ceremony done to the dead,
The noble dead: come, let's go burn the body.

sp.speaker: Petill.
sp.l: The regiment given from me; disgraced openly;
In love too with a trifle to abuse me?
A merry world, a fine world: served seven years
To be an ass of both sides, sweet Petillius,
You have brought your hogs to a fine market: you are wise, sir,
Your honourable brainpan full of crotchets,
An understanding gentleman; your projects
Cast with assurance ever: wouldst not thou now
Be banged about the pate, Petillius?
Answer to that sweet soldier; surely, surely,
I think ye would; pulled by the nose, kicked; hang thee,
Thou art the arrantest rascal: trust thy wisdom
With any thing of weight; the wind with feathers.
Out ye blind puppy; you command? you govern?
Dig for a groat a day, or serve a swineherd;
Too noble for thy nature too. I must up;
But what I shall do there, let time discover. Exit.

div.head: Scaena tertia.
div.stage: Enter Macer and Judas, with meat and a bottle.

sp.speaker: Mac.
sp.l: Hang it o'th' side o'th' rock, as though the Britain's
Stole hither to relieve him; who first ventures
To fetch it off, is ours. I cannot see him.

sp.speaker: Jud.
sp.l: He lies close in a hole above, I know it,
Gnawing upon his anger: ha? no, 'tis not he,

sp.speaker: Macer
sp.l: 'Tis but the shaking of the boughs.

sp.speaker: Jud.
sp.l: — shake 'em,
I am sure they shake me soundly. There.

sp.speaker: Macer
sp.l: 'Tis nothing.

sp.speaker: Jud.
sp.l: Make no noise: if he stir, a deadly tempest
Of huge stones fall upon us: 'tis done: away close.Exit.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: Sleep still, sleep sweetly child, 'tis all thou feedest on.
No gentle Britain near; no valiant charity
To bring thee food? poor knave, thou art sick, extreme sick,
Almost grown wild for meat; and yet thy goodness
Will not confess, nor show it. All the woods
Are double lined with soldiers; no way left us
To make a noble scape: I'll sit down by thee,
And when thou wakest, either get meat to save thee,
Or lose my life i'th' purchase. Good gods comfort thee.

sp.speaker: Guide
sp.l: Ye are not far off now, sir.

sp.speaker: Jun.
sp.l: Draw the companies
The closest way thorough the woods; we'll keep on this way.

sp.speaker: Guide
sp.l: I will sir: half a furlong more you'll come
Within the sight o'th' rock; keep on the left side,
You'll be discovered else: I'll lodge your companies
In the wild vines beyond ye.

sp.speaker: Dec.
sp.l: Do ye mark him?

sp.speaker: Jun.
sp.l: Yes, and am sorry for him.

sp.speaker: Petill.
sp.l: Junius,
Pray let me speak two words with you.

sp.speaker: Jun.
sp.l: Walk afore,
I'll overtake ye straight.

sp.speaker: Dec.
sp.l: I will. Exit.

sp.speaker: Jun.
sp.l: Now, captain.

sp.speaker: Petill.
sp.l: You have oft told me, you have loved me, Junius.

sp.speaker: Jun.
sp.l: Most sure I told you truth then.

sp.speaker: Petill.
sp.l: And that love
Should not deny me any honest thing.

sp.speaker: Jun.
sp.l: It shall not.

sp.speaker: Petill.
sp.l: Dare ye swear it?
I have forgotten all passages between us
That have been ill, forgiven too, forgotten you.

sp.speaker: Jun.
sp.p: What would this man have? By — I do, sir, so it be fit to grant ye.

sp.speaker: Petill.
sp.l: 'Tis most honest.

sp.speaker: Jun.
sp.l: Why, then I'll do it.

sp.speaker: Petill.
sp.l: Kill me.

sp.speaker: Jun.
sp.l: How?

sp.speaker: Petill.
sp.l: Pray kill me.

sp.speaker: Jun.
sp.l: Kill ye?

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: Ay, kill me quickly, suddenly,
Now kill me.

sp.speaker: Jun.
sp.l: On what reason? ye amaze me.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: If ye do love me, kill me, ask me not why:
I would be killed, and by you.

sp.speaker: Jun.
sp.l: Mercy on me,
What ails this man? Petillius.

sp.speaker: Petill.
sp.l: Pray ye dispatch me,
Ye are not safe whilst I live: I am dangerous,
Troubled extremely, even to mischief, Junius,
An enemy to all good men: fear not, 'tis justice;
I shall kill you else.

sp.speaker: Jun.
sp.l: Tell me but the cause,
And I will do it.

sp.speaker: Petill.
sp.l: I am disgraced, my service
Slighted, and unrewarded by the general,
My hopes left wild and naked; besides these,
I am grown ridiculous, an ass, a folly
I dare not trust myself with: prithee kill me.

sp.speaker: Jun.
sp.l: All these may be redeemed as easily
As you would heal your finger.

sp.speaker: Petill.
sp.l: Nay —

sp.speaker: Jun.
sp.l: Stay, I'll do it,
You shall not need your anger: but first, Petillius,
You shall unarm yourself; I dare not trust
A man so bent to mischief.

sp.speaker: Petill.
sp.l: There's my sword;
And do it handsomely.

sp.speaker: Jun.
sp.l: Yes, I will kill ye,
Believe that certain: but first I'll lay before ye
The most extreme fool ye have played in this,
The honour purposed for ye, the great honour
The general intended ye,

sp.speaker: Petill.
sp.l: How?

sp.speaker: Jun.
sp.l: And then I'll kill ye,
Because ye shall die miserable. Know sir,
The regiment was given me, but till time
Called ye to do some worthy deed might stop
The people's ill thoughts of ye for lord Penyus,
I mean his death. How soon this time's come to ye,
And hasted by Swetonius? Go, says he,
Junius and Decius, and go thou Petillius;
Distinctly, thou Petillius, and draw up,
To take stout Caratach: there's the deed purposed,
A deed to take off all faults, of all natures:
And thou Petillius; mark it, there's the honour,
And that done, all made even.

sp.speaker: Petill.
sp.l: Stay.

sp.speaker: Jun.
sp.l: No, I'll kill ye.
He knew thee absolute, and full in soldier,
Daring beyond all dangers, found thee out
According to the boldness of thy spirit,
A subject, such a subject.

sp.speaker: Petill.
sp.l: Hark ye Junius,
I will live now.

sp.speaker: Jun.
sp.l: By no means. Wooed thy worth,
Held thee by the chin up, as thou sank'st, and showed thee
How honour held her arms out: come, make ready,
Since ye will die an ass.

sp.speaker: Petil.
sp.l: Thou wilt not kill me.

sp.speaker: Jun.
sp.l: By — but I will sir: I'll have no man dangerous
Live to destroy me afterwards. Besides, you have gotten
Honour enough, let young men rise now. Nay,
I do perceive too by the general, (Which is
One main cause ye shall die) howe'er he carry it,
Such a strong doting on ye, that I fear,
You shall command in chief: how are we paid then?
Come, if you will pray, dispatch it.

sp.speaker: Petill.
sp.l: Is there no way?

sp.speaker: Jun.
sp.l: Not any way to live.

sp.speaker: Petill.
sp.l: I will do any thing,
Redeem myself at any price: good Junius,
Let me but die upon the rock, but offer
My life up like a soldier.

sp.speaker: Jun.
sp.l: You will seek then
To outdo every man.

sp.speaker: Petill.
sp.l: Believe it Junius,
You shall go stroke by stroke with me.

sp.speaker: Jun.
sp.l: You'll leave off too,
As you are noble, and a soldier,
For ever these mad fancies.

sp.speaker: Petill.
sp.l: Dare ye trust me?
By all that's good and honest.

sp.speaker: Jun.
sp.l: There's your sword then,
And now come on a new man: virtue guide thee. Exeunt.

div.stage: Enter Caratach and Hengo on the rock.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: Courage my boy, I have found meat: look Hengo,
Look where some blessed Britain, to preserve thee,
Has hung a little food and drink: cheer up boy,
Do not forsake me now.

sp.speaker: Hengo.
sp.l: O uncle, uncle,
I feel I cannot stay long: yet I'll fetch it,
To keep your noble life: uncle, I am heart whole,
And would live.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: Thou shalt, long I hope.

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.l: But my head, uncle:
Methinks the rock goes round. Enter Macer and Jud.

sp.speaker: Macer.
sp.l: Mark 'em well, Judas.

sp.speaker: Jud.
sp.l: Peace, as you love your life.

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.l: Do not you hear
The noise of bells?

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: Of bells boy? 'tis thy fancy,
Alas, thy body's full of wind.

sp.speaker: Hengo.
sp.l: Methinks sir,
They ring a strange sad knell, a preparation
To some near funeral of state: nay, weep not,
Mine own sweet uncle, you will kill me sooner.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: O my poor chicken.

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.l: Fie, faint-hearted uncle:
Come, tie me in your belt, and let me down.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: I'll go myself, boy.

sp.speaker: Hengo
sp.l: No, as ye love me, uncle;
I will not eat it, if I do not fetch it;
The danger only I desire: pray tie me.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: I will, and all my care hang o'er thee: come child,
My valiant-child.

sp.speaker: Hengo
sp.l: Let me down apace, uncle,
And ye shall see how like a daw I'll whip it
From all their policies: for 'tis most certain
A Roman train: and ye must hold me sure too,
You'll spoil all else. When I have brought it uncle,
We'll be as merry —

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: Go i'th' name of heaven boy.

sp.speaker: Hengo
sp.l: Quick, quick, uncle, I have it. Oh.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: What ailest thou?

sp.speaker: Hengo
sp.l: O my best uncle, I am slain.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: I see ye, and heaven direct my hand: destruction
sp.stage: Caratach kills Judas with a stone from the rock.
sp.l: Go with thy coward soul. How dost thou boy?
O villain, pocky villain.

sp.speaker: Hengo
sp.l: O uncle, uncle,
O how it pricks me: am I preserved for this?
Extremely pricks me.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: Coward, rascal coward,
Dogs eat thy flesh.

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.l: O I bleed hard: I faint too, out upon 't,
How sick I am? the lean rogue, uncle.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: Look boy,
I have laid him sure enough.

sp.speaker: Hengo
sp.l: Have ye knocked his brains out?

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: I warrant thee for stirring more: cheer up, child.

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.l: Hold my sides hard, stop, stop, o wretched fortune,
Must we part thus? Still I grow sicker, uncle.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: Heaven look upon this noble child.

sp.speaker: Hengo
sp.l: I once hoped
I should have lived to have met these bloody Romans
At my sword's point, to have revenged my father,
To have beaten 'em: o hold me hard. But uncle —

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: Thou shalt live still I hope boy. Shall I draw it?

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.l: Ye draw away my soul then. I would live
A little longer; spare me heavens, but only
To thank you for your tender love. Good uncle,
Good noble uncle weep not.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: O my chicken,
My dear boy, what shall I lose?

sp.speaker: Hengo
sp.l: Why, a child,
That must have died however: had this scaped me,
Fever or famine: I was born to die, sir.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: But thus unblown, my boy?

sp.speaker: Heng.
sp.l: I go the straighter
My journey to the gods: sure I shall know ye
When ye come, uncle.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: Yes, boy.

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.l: And I hope
We shall enjoy together that great blessedness
You told me of.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: Most certain, child.

sp.speaker: Hengo
sp.l: I grow cold,
Mine eyes are going.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: Lift 'em up.

sp.speaker: Hengo
sp.l: Pray for me;
And noble uncle, when my bones are ashes,
Think of your little nephew. Mercy.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: Mercy.
You blessed angels take him.

sp.speaker: Hengo
sp.l: Kiss me: so.
Farewell, farewell. Dies.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: Farewell the hopes of Britain,
Thou royal graft, farewell for ever. Time and death,
Ye have done your worst. Fortune now see, now proudly
Pluck off thy vail, and view thy triumph: look,
Look what thou hast brought this land to. O fair flower,
How lovely yet thy ruins show, how sweetly
Even death embraces thee! The peace of heaven,
The fellowship of all great souls be with thee.
sp.stage: Enter Petillius and Junius on the rock.
sp.l: Ha? dare ye Romans? ye shall win me bravely.
Thou art mine. Fight.

sp.speaker: Jun.
sp.l: Not yet, sir.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: Breathe ye, ye poor Romans,
And come up all, with all your ancient valours,
Like a rough wind I'll shake your souls, and send 'em —

div.stage: Enter Swetonius, and all the Roman captains.

sp.speaker: Swet.
sp.l: Yield thee bold Caratach; by all —
As I am soldier, as I envy thee,
I'll use thee like thyself, the valiant Britain.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: Brave soldier yield; thou stock of arms and honour,
Thou filler of the world with fame and glory.

sp.speaker: Jun.
sp.l: Most worthy man, we'll woo thee, be thy prisoners.

sp.speaker: Swet.
sp.l: Excellent Britain, do me but that honour,
That more to me then conquests, that true happiness,
To be my friend.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: O Romans, see what here is:
Had this boy lived —

sp.speaker: Swet.
sp.l: For fame's sake, for thy sword's sake,
As thou desirest to build thy virtues greater:
By all that's excellent in man, and honest —

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: I do believe: ye have had me a brave foe;
Make me a noble friend, and from your goodness,
Give this boy honourable earth to lie in.

sp.speaker: Swet.
sp.l: He shall have fitting funeral.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: I yield then,
Not to your blows, but your brave courtesies.

sp.speaker: Petill.
sp.l: Thus we conduct then to the arms of peace
The wonder of the world.

sp.speaker: Swet.
sp.l: Thus I embrace thee,Flourish.
And let it be no flattery that I tell thee,
Thou art the only soldier.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: How to thank ye
I must hereafter find upon your usage.
I am for Rome?

sp.speaker: Swet.
sp.l: Ye must.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: Then Rome shall know
The man that makes her spring of glory grow.

sp.speaker: Swet.
sp.l: Petillius, you have shown much worth this day,
Redeemed much error,
Ye have my love again, preserve it. Junius,
With you I make him equal in the regiment.

sp.speaker: Jun.
sp.l: The elder and the nobler: I'll give place, sir.

sp.speaker: Swet.
sp.l: Ye show a friend's soul.
March on, and through the camp in every tongue.
The virtues of great Caratach be sung. Exeunt.

div.head: Textual Notes
div.p: The textual notes below aim at making textual corrections readable in their immediate context and facilitating access to the source text. A five-dit number preceded by 'A' or 'B' represents an EEBO-TCP filenumber. A notation like "6-b-2890" means "look for EEBO page image 6 of that text, word 289 on the right side of the double-page image." That reference is followed by the corrupt reading. A black dot stands for an unidentified letter, a black square for an unidentified punctuation mark, a diamond for a missing word, and the ellipsis for a short span of undefined length. The corrected reading is displayed as a kewyord in context.
